Question: How protected is it from being dropped? Will the screen crack? Can the sides get chipped or scratced as well?
Answer: I'd hate to have to actually "test" this product with my new phone, but it's a very secure hard plastic shell which is in cased in a faux leather-like billfold flip cover. Appears to me you'd have to have the cover open and slam it on a pretty hard surface to possibly do any damage so I'm pretty confident of its impact safety. Sides and back are completely secure. With glass there's always a chance of cracking but the screen protector that comes with it is a slight deterrent.

Question: Just received this item, absolutely no instructions and I am unable to pair it to my I phone 5. Any suggestions or is there a way to acquire instruct
Answer: Mine came with a little 1 page instruction sheet. I paired mine to an iPhone 5, so yes. The 'phone/power' button also triggers pairing. Press and hold the 'phone/power' button for 7 seconds. The light will flash red and blue. That signals pairing mode. On your iPhone, goto Bluetooth settings. You should see SP100340. Select that. If asked for a password, enter 1234. Paired. All buttons are multifunction. +/- short press= switch song; long press= volume Music: short press phone/power to pause start. Phone: short press to answer; long press to refuse

Question: Not very happy with this - I have yet to get it to work. After it's charged, how long does it hold it's charge if it's sitting dormant?
Answer: Hi. It should double your phone's battery life. If your phone gets depleted after 8-12 hours of use then it is safe to assume that your total estimated battery life with the case is 16-24 hours. You can turn off the case when not in use. Just press and hold the power switch to turn the battery power on and off, and press it once to see the battery's status.

Question: Where to you pry it open? What area of the case. I don't wnt to break it
Answer: I just did it, but it was not obvious. The people who say to remove the silicone cover first are right. The key is that you have to realize that the silicone cover is one big piece -- I kept trying to find a seam to separate it. Instead, hold the case as if you were looking at the phone, and bend back the silicone cover at the corners (away from you). Do that on all 4 corners of the screen -- you'll need to stretch it a bit, but it will come off. Then, you'll just have the hard inner case, which is opened by popping the 2 tabs on the side and the 1 at the top.

Question: how do you get the case open to put it on the phone?
Answer: Remove the rubber part from the top, then pull it out of the bottom. Then lightly lift the square clips on the side from the back. There are three; one on top and one on each side. Pull apart then insert the phone. Snap the hard case back together, and replace the rubber , making sure the rubber snaps around the tabs you opened the plastic box with.

Question: Can the ipad sit in the back dock with a case on? What are the measurements of that space?

The new Targus case I have does not fit in the docking station unless I only use the back flap of the case in the slot provided to prop the iPad up. So to answer the question the iPad itself is not in the docking slot, rather cover for my iPad sits in the slot and works perfectly well in my situation. My wife has a Oberon case and does not fit in the slot at all. I think the docking station was designed for the iPad to be used without any protective case, with seems like an oversite. The dimension of the slot the iPad sits in is 11/16 inch wide, 1/2 inch deep, with the bak plate it rests on 1 1/4 inch high. If I can be of any further help let me know.

Question: Will this work with ios 7 on an iphone 5 ? I have a case now that says its not compatible and will not charge wish i could downgrade from ios 7
Answer: It works great with any iOS device and any version, you just have to know how. Once you plug in the charging cable to the phone (battery pack) push the on button on the battery pack, you will see the phone charging and the first light (light) on the battery pack on without blinking. Once the phone is fully charged, the first light (led) will sart to flash and then the other 3 until all 4 are on without blinking. You will notice that in the morning the phone is at about 97 to 95% of charge, this is normal due the time that has elapsed from when the phone stoped charging the battery and switched over to the battery pack. When you see that the battery of the phone is almost drained, just push the on button on the battery pack and the battery pack will start charging your phone. The blue lights (leds) will start flashing 4,3,2,1 off. Your phone should be fully charged and the battery pack empty

Question: Can this speaker be continually plugged in or does that ruin the battery life?
Answer: It is OK to keep it continuously plugged in. When the Cyren is off and fully charged and USB connected to 5.14V, it draws 0.00 Amps (I have a USB volt-amp meter). The battery is being charged only when it needs to be charged, and that is good for the battery.

Question: My ph-BT1000 can't pair with my Ipad Air nor my laptop. It paired with my Iphone OK, is there any updates or patches that can improve discoverability?
Answer: It is likely still paired with your IPhone. Once the speaker is paired with a device it remains paired to that device. Turn Bluetooth off on your IPhone and put the speaker back into pairing mode (power down, wait 10secs and power back on). You will know it is in pairing mode when it flashes Red and Blue. Keep in mind the speaker will automatically pair with any previously paired device thereby blocking any other new device pairings.

Question: 12 volt re-charge?
Answer: It's a 5-v USB-powered device...So any 5-v USB power adapter or USB hub or computer port will power and charge the speaker.

Question: Since this does not come with a charger, is there a recommended max Amperage to charge this with?
Answer: I have a USB volt-amp meter. When the Cyren is off and USB connected and charging, the USB is at 5.11V and the Cyren is drawing 580 mA. A computer USB port must source at least 500 mA. So, if you have a dedicated USB power source that supplies more than 500 mA, like 1 Amp or 2 Amp, it would charge the Cyren a little faster, but not much faster.

Question: Which is better this Cyren speaker or The OontZ Angle Ultra-Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker?
Answer: I had the same question. Thanks for bringing this up. I studied internet to find this answer for two days. And this is what I find: 1. Cyren is slightly richer in bass than Oontz Angle 2. Cyren is better looking, though some people like the way angle points upwards towards listeners when you place it on a table (waist height). But I like the simple look of Cyren better ... goes well with my book-rack 3. In one of the you tube review I can see Cyren has two speakers 40mm diameter and probably a central woofer (I am not sure). I definitely see an impression of speaker diaphram in center ... I am not sure if Oontz has that. 4. A number of websit, including http://www.bestwirelessspeakersreview.com/reviews/ constantly top-rated Cyren ... compared to Oontz 5. By looking at the picture I felt Oontz ... toy like with a flashy LED... and many complain low-bass. I felt Cyren was more serious shaped and people say it has slightly more bass and power than Oontz. 6. Number of reviews 1800 for Cyren and 1200+ for Oontz .......both average 4.5 in Amazon ...... onbiously more people trust Cyren. That may be due to earlier release date of Cyren. But I believe in peoples' trust ... the more the number of rating the more its time tested. 7. If price speaks of quality ... then note you are getting around 70% discount on 120 USD speaker (Cyren), where as around 43% discount on 70% speaker (Oontz Angle) ...... Waiting for it to arrive. Will know for sure once I ear it.

Question: It Does fit with cd player of toyota corolla 2009? Is compatible with Samsung S3 Mini?
Answer: Hi Victoriano - Yes to both. The Toyota Corolla center media dash has a slightly wide angle somewhere between 90 and 120 degrees which is compatible with this mount. In terms of views, the mount can be adjusted to accommodate 360 movement, side to side placement for full driver and passenger views as well as vertical tilt positioning. The stock CD drive itself is also compatible with the mount wedge inserts. The Samsung S3 Mini is 63mm or 2.48 inches wide and approx .4 inches deep which will fit comfortably in the mount. Thanks! Cost Brothers

Question: How do you charge the battery? Can you charge while it in in use (ie you want to use it longer than the battery charge)?
Answer: The CoolStream Portable speaker comes with a charging cable. One end is a standard USB connector and the other end is a barrel shaped connector that fits into the DC jack in the back of the speaker. You can charge the speaker by plugging the USB cable into your computer or an outlet charger that has a USB port. Yes, you can use the speaker while charging it.

Question: Can I play iTunes formatted music from an USB or SD or do I need to convert the iTunes to MP3 format?
Answer: The CoolStream Portable Bluetooth speaker only supports the playback of only MP3 format. So yes, you will need to convert iTunes format to MP3 when using an USB thumb drive or SD card.

Question: Does anyone have feedback on the speaker phone quality / use ? Thx

Question: do you need to pay and can this work with a unlocked lg g3
Answer: Yes, it will work with an unlocked GSM LG G3. Watch for a sale or promotion. These activation kits with SIM are frequently discounted. You need to buy time to use the phone. $3 per month includes 30 minutes of talk or 30 text messages - or any combination of the two, up to 30 - and lets you keep your phone number from month to month. Add additional talk and text at a low flat rate of 10 cents per minute or message (sending and receiving). If you buy $100 of time, for example, it will decrease by $3/mo even if you don't use the phone. Minutes used up to 30 cost $3 if used or not. Minutes over 30 cost $0.10/min. No rollover of minutes.

Question: Is the camera really 13 megapixel?
Answer: The new HTC One will be the first to feature the HTC UltraPixel Camera - an advanced imaging technology that offers a great leap in the quality of point-and-shoot photos and video. Smartphones have rapidly become the primary camera for millions of people, and taking pictures has become an indispensable part of daily life. HTC is committed to offering the highest quality camera available, so even everyday pictures are gratifying and memorable. With our new camera, you'll be able to quickly shoot vivid, true-to-life images with a wide range of colors, even in low light conditions. We accomplish this not by increasing the number of megapixels in the camera, but by engineering a more advanced CMOS Sensor, ISP, and optical lens system that captures significantly more light than most 8 or 13 megapixel cameras. "We shouldn't scrap pixel count entirely when weighing smartphone cameras, but in terms of the hardware and software details that actually go into making a great photo, megapixels are highly overrated. It's high time we focus on other areas that count more, like that undersung sensor. Jessica Dolcourt, CNET May 12, 2012 In this section we will describe for you how we've created the most sensitive smartphone camera, which include these key components of ImageSense technology: UltraPixel Sensor - Engineered with larger pixels, it enables each pixel to capture more than 300% more light than most leading 13 megapixel cameras. HTC ImageChip - Offers continuous autofocus, color shading, and noise reduction, as well as more realistic High Dynamic Range. F/2.0 Aperture - The largest available smartphone camera aperture, it lets in 44% more light than the iPhone 5. Optical Image Stabilization - Drastically reduces blur in still photos and shaky video footage.

Question: I stay in an apartment. Can I just don't use the Outdoor monitor and still use the weather station ?
Answer: Yes you can no problem

Question: Does the Indoor Weather Station unit still have the option for both battery (and USB) power or is it now USB only?...
Answer: Primary is plugged into a outlet, and the secondary purchased units for additional rooms, are battery only.

Question: Can I use outside this inside unit???
Answer: The outside unit has special sealing to protect against damage from moisture plus has also a wall fitting. The indoor unit cannot be easily exchanged with an outdoor one.

Question: If I add an additional indoor module....can I monitor co2 in the room ? does this just work like the base indoor module and provide all those details?
Answer: The add-on indoor modules have their own individual CO2 sensors

Question: Do i have to buy the whole weather system or can i just buy the indoor ones ?
Answer: You have to buy the indoor "base station" which comes with a single outdoor station. Only then can you add additional modules.

Question: Will the indoor unit operate on its own without purchasing the Weather Station kit that includes the outdoor unit? I only need indoor units.
Answer: No. The indoor units are additional, secondary transmitters that talk to the primary indoor unit provided in the Weather Station kit. The primary unit is needed to report the information over the Internet. The secondary units cannot do this.

Question: Not sure how many modules you can add. I have two now and my display reads three units. Can I add one more? Does the outdoor module count as one.
Answer: per Netamo you can install three Indoor modules. The outdoor does not count as an Indoor module.

Question: Are the waterproof version and non-waterproof version the same size and do they both allow headphones?
Answer: I only have the waterproof version so I can't respond to your question about sizing. In regards to your question about headphones you could use headphones and still be weatherproof but not water tight. In order to be water tight you need to seal the closure (like a zip lock bag) before you fold over and velcro the top flap over the closure. In order to use headphones with a cord you wouldn't be able to fully seal the zip lock closure and therefore would not be water tight. Having said this, however, I still believe that your equipment would be protected from the elements because the velcro flap folds over that closure. Since the closure and velcro flap are located on the top your equipment would almost certainly be protected if you used the mount in its vertical position. If you used it horizontally you might increase the chances of moisture getting in but you would really need a driving rain in order to do so. Also, you should be able to route your cord so it exits on a corner and you would then be able to mostly seal the zip lock, too, thereby increasing it's weather resistance.

Question: How does the battery fit in the charger? I put mine in..the light turned blue right away I left it plugged in all night. But was dead when put in phon
Answer: There should be two positive/negative contact markings on the battery. Make sure those line up with the contacts on the charger. The light should turn purple once an uncharged battery is put in correctly. When not charging a battery the light will be blue. Here's a picture: http://imgur.com/uYFAktx . It's upside down in that photo to accomodate my other plugs, but you can see how the battery is oriented.

Question: are the volume buttons and power switch covered? also, what is the difference between this case and the slim armor s?
Answer: The volume and power button are covered by very smooth and responsive buttons. The buttons push as if they are a part of the device with, completely natural. The slim armor is a thin rigid skin type case. It is open on the top and bottom but still provides a lot of protection. This case was dropped and provided better protection then I ever imagined. The back plate is made from a very beautiful brushed aluminum piece. The slim armor is the closest thing to a raw no case feel you can get with a lot of protection. You would be happy with either case. I use the neo hybrid for work and out about trips and the slim armor at home and running errands.

Question: Does the case block the flash? Do pictures come out obscured by the flash due to the case in dark situations?

Question: I remove my case several times per week to put it in my armband when I work out. Is this case going to hold up?

Question: I have dropped my phone a couple of times, will this case protect against this.

Question: I know that the Boost Mobile Galaxy S2 has mobile hotspot capabilities, but does the Galaxy S3 have Built-in mobile hotspot functionality?
Answer: S2 only has hotspot capabilities IF you already own it AND the phone is in service. My fiance has an S2, lost it and sent for new one from insurance. In mean time he bought the S3 because he needs a phone for his business. He planned on giving me the new phone when his came insurance. Because he switched his service from the S2 to the S3 for less than a week, he lost his hotspot capabilities and only can get that back if he pays $10 a month. So beware, if you happen to buy an S2 phone, you will not get hotspot unless you pay for it.

Question: is this phone unlocked

Question: if i purchase this phone, can i chose my carrier or do i have to go with Boost!
Answer: Hi, if it specifically states "Boost Mobile", it can only be used with Boost Mobile!!! However, sometimes you can find tech experts that can "unblock" the phone so that you can use other carriers!!! Don't buy one of these phones to unblock unless you know of someone who can do it!!! That being said, carriers that support this phone will usually have their name in the title when you're searching for these phones!!! If it's a Boost, it'll list Boost, if it's Verizon, it'll list Verizon, etc.!!! Good luck!!!

Question: what does triband mean?
Answer: Around the world cell phone operate on three different frequencies. If your phone is triband (most new ones are) this means it will work anywhere in the world. Probably not that important unless you travel a lot. Cell phones are locked so that it will only be compatable with individual providers. If it is locked with Cingular it will not work with Verizon. There are methods available to unlock them, but more than likely too advanced for the common consumer, unless you have an electronics knowledge base, then if that is the case....google, "unlock cellphone."

This Limited Warranty covers batteries only if battery capacity falls below 80% of rated capacity or the battery leaks, and this Limited Warranty does not cover any battery if (i) the battery has been charged by a battery charger not specified or approved by SAMSUNG for charging the battery; (ii) any of the seals on the battery are broken or show evidence of tampering; or (iii) the battery has been used in equipment other than the SAMSUNG phone for which it is specified. What are SAMSUNG's obligations? During the applicable warranty period, provided the Product is returned in accordance with the terms of this Limited Warranty, SAMSUNG will repair or replace the Product, at SAMSUNG'S sole option, without charge. SAMSUNG may, at SAMSUNG's sole option, use rebuilt, reconditioned, or new parts or components when repairing any Product, or may replace the Product with a rebuilt, reconditioned or new Product. Repaired/replaced cases, pouches and holsters will be warranted for a period of ninety (90) days. All other repaired/replaced Products will be warranted for a period equal to the remainder of the original Limited Warranty on the original Product or for ninety (90) days, whichever is longer. All replaced Products, parts, components, boards and equipment shall become the property of SAMSUNG. Except to any extent expressly allowed by applicable law, transfer or assignment of this Limited Warranty is prohibited.

Question: Is the backside of this item neoprene, and does it look the seams will stay sewn/ hold up? Also want to know if you can press side buttons easily.
Answer: The side button press is "okay" at best, sometimes I have to push in a few times to find where the buttons are. As for the neoprene, it goes the entire way around on the back of the main section as well as the straps. The strap is actually where I have the biggest problem for this item. I have had it for about 2 months, and use it roughly 3-4 times per week at Planet Fitness using their machines and free-weights. I am 6'1" and 180 lbs, looking to add muscle, but am not overly muscular currently. After this moderate use over the last 2 months I have recently had to stop using this product as the velcro no longer stays attached. The "loop" side of the hook-and-loop has become significantly frayed and won't stay attached. The only way it would work would be for me to sew on new loop material or to move it to a thicker part of my arm to change where the velcro attaches to itself. Although I am disappointed in this products life-span I guess at the price point I got what I paid for.

All together, I don't think this has any stereo effects worth mentioning but, it is impressive in other ways. Mind you, you are getting this information from a cheap guy. Question: Does the charger stop when the phone is fully charged or will it still send an electric current to the phone?
Answer: The Samsung Galaxy S5 includes logic to enable the Qi wireless charging process. According to the Qi specification, communication is one way from the receiver (S5 + receiver coil in this case) to the transmitter (charger pad). The receiver modulates the wireless charging field to send requests back to the charger pad for more or less power. In the case of the S5, it never tells the charger pad to turn off when it's at 100% charge. It tells the charger pad to reduce the charge to a minimum. Other devices, such as the Nexus 4, may tell the charger pad to turn off when it hits 100%.

Question: Will this charger automatically adjust the current or will it fry it? I have a phone that requires 1.0A and dont want extra current flowing..
Answer: The device being charged regulates the rate at which the battery is charged. So if you have a charger that charges at a low rate, the device being charged is limited to the lower rate of the charger. But if you have 3.1 amps available, some devices can charge very quickly. With modern charging circuits, having more than enough current available is a good thing!

Question: Are you able to download apps because someone else said it is not from Samsung and has useless apps?
Answer: I purchased it initially after extensive research about the FEATURES of the phone. I was satisfied and bought it from here. However, I did NO research on whether it had ever been produced factory sealed without connection to a service, which apparently it does not. Mine came from Vodacom, a company I've had a service with before, so I was somewhat familiar with the apps they add to the phone, which, like the Samsung Apps, can NEVER be removed without rooting the phone (which is a little like jailbreaking an iPhone, but slightly riskier). I have not rooted it, but have hidden the samsung and Vodacom apps from all menus, but they still pop up from time to time when it reboots. As for the android system, it can receive new apps from the Google Play store completely as normal. Also, Vodacom finally pushed a global KitKat update on these, FINALLY. Before then you had to go to a shop to update it, and Vodacom doesn't have shops in my current country!

Question: What is the difference between the models 14s and 14?
Answer: Actually Its (i4) I4s and I4. I4 is bluetooth 2.0 and has raised option buttons on the device for play, stop, etc,. I4s is bluetooth 3.0 ( better range, better battery life, faster data transfer if your using it for such a task) and is backwards compatible with 2.0 devices. Also the option buttons are flat and flush with the device which makes for a seamless and smooth look and feel.

Question: I got i4s but couldn't get it paired with Samsung phones. Hold the button to see the blue light flash quickly but the phone couldn't find it.

Turn off and then turn on your samsung bluetooth and it should start searching for the i4s, if not, push the samsung bluetooth search for new device to find it. You should see the i4s show up on Samsung bluetooth list. Check the instruction sheet that came with i4s for a more detailed instruction.

Question: how many charges for iphone until battery is dead
Answer: I see this as 2 questions : 1) how many times can you charge before having to recharge the remote charger - well that is purely a matter of from which state you charge from - I myself has charged more than 10 times before charging the remote charger again, however if the phone is totally down each time you charge it's another matter - then maybe two to three times before charging the remote charger again. 2) When is the battery totally dead and you have to buy a new charger - this is a matter of where you contain the charger on a daily basis (a cool place is better than directly in the sun) and again a matter of from which state you charge from, so it is in fact impossible to say,however, I have had my own for a year now, and it is still functioning. When this is said, then it is not necessary to buy a new charger if you use one with a replaceable battery as for example our stainless steel charger, which also have a larger capacity than the one in question - try to look after ASIN B00I01P196 in the amazon store.

Question: Do you have to buy a Card every Month to keep your Phone Service Activated? Also, are there any Additional Hidden Fees, or is it $20 a Month TOTAL??
Answer: I am not sure if there is a "card." $20 gives you 30 days of service. You can pay up a few months in advance or go to your local AT&T store each month and pay $20 on your account. We pay monthly because the service is still new, and we're not sure if we'll experience problems. There are zero additional fees because we activated our unit at our local store as a PREPAID account. We paid in advance for 30 days of service and did not allow them to bill us. Customers who have activated online seem to receive bills with fees. Account must be PREPAID.

Question: Does the phome have a battery back up for power outages?

Question: I bought one and either I threw the charger instructions away or there were none in the box? Does the blue light ever go out?
Answer: No. Blue light shows power on (NO battery in) OR full charge (battery in). Light turns red when battery is charging. Turns back to blue when battery full. Interestingly enough, as the battery is charging, you might see a combination of red & blue (purple) light as the battery gets close to full charge. But when the battery is in place (correctly) and the light is blue, the battery is fully charged.

Question: how do you know it is charged? does the light go off?
Answer: I just got 2 of these on sale including all the adapters. I charge the Stick with wall charger that's included because it charges in about 30 minutes. There's a Red light that comes on when the Stick itself is charging. The light does go out when the stick is fully charged. Then when you plug the Stick into your Phone/other device there's a Blue light that indicates it's charging your Phone/device. When your Phone/device is fully charged the blue light goes out. I'm not quite sure yet what they're referring to when they say there's an LED battery level indicator, unless they're referring to the little "battery icon" that shows up on the ipone that tells you how much power is left in your phone. It charged my iphone very quickly too. Both are pretty new, so I'm hoping these quick charges continue for awhile. There's nothing in the tiny bit of instructions that indicates the stick can be overcharged, so I'm also hoping that since the lights go out when charges are "full" that nothing will overcharge. It's also nice to have the extra Wall Charger (with a USB port) to use with multiple devices, since practically everything for iphones are sold separately, i.e. the extra Lightning-USB cable does not come with the plug in wall charger. Wall chargers always charge all devices faster than charging from a USB port on your computer laptop. I like "Quick" !!

Question: What does the "Unlocked International Version" mean??

Question: how are they for running? do they fit snug in ear so won't fall out?

As a matter of fact I just got through cutting grass and sweated pretty good. No problem with them staying in my ears. If you get them once you and play with them a while you will figure out what angle to put the stabilizer in for the perfect fit. You will also know when you got a good fit because they sound awsome! They are best I have had so far. I have LG730 and they always have a tendency to fall out after sweating, so I stopped wearing them for workouts. I think these are a good buy.

Question: I can't get it connected to my mini iPad. Please advise
Answer: Try this: 1. Power off the headphones 2. On the iPad Mini, go to Settings, Bluetooth 3. Power on the headphones, continue holding the button until the light blinks red and blue (pairing mode) 4. The headphones will appear under Bluetooth as PLT_BBTGO2, tap it to pair 5. Once the pairing is complete, the status will show as "Connected" I just tried this on my iPhone running IOS7 and it worked perfectly, should work the same for an iPad. Give it a try with these instructions.

Question: I signed up with Metro PCS (T-MOBILE 3G resources) similar to Straight Talk etc. However, I'm only getting "Tmobiles 2g" in Pomona, CA. Any ideas?

I couldnt access 3G either; a friend of mine looked at it and found the frequency range. Another thing; yesterday the phone fall down from about a meter high; wasnt that high, the cristal screen totaly broke; since I live in Central America, theres no place to repair it. I owned before a Samsung Galaxy S3 and had some very hard falls and never happened to me. There went my 200 dollars. Take care of it, for the months that I had it, I mostly used it only with Wifi.

Question: Has anyone found a way to turn on/off gps? I am using a GS4 and have tried several apps.
Answer: I use an app called tasker with my nfc. tasker is an automation tool and can do all kinds of cool things. if my nfc writer can't perform some action, I'll turn to tasker and define a set of steps I want done. some nfc writers allow you to call a tasker set of instructions. So, even though the nfc writer might not do the job, because tasker can be called from nfc we can add functionality. good luck!

Question: My Note 3 tells me "This tag is not supported". Did I get sent the wrong product?
Answer: Although, I'm not a expert on the subject, my research keeps coming up with compatible with the mini note 3. My question is what's the mini(neo) and is there a non-mini. Do you have access to any non-tectile nfc tags, maybe a friends. you could see if you can read other types of nfc tags to confirm that it's the tectile and not something else that's causing the problem. If it's saying "This tag is not supported" then we can deduce that the nfc antenna picked up something. Also, check for any software updates for your phone before testing further. Good Luck!

Question: Perhaps I missed this bit of info, but are these rewriteable? Thanks in advance for any responses.
Answer: yes they are rewritable until you permanently write them. there are options to write onto tags and permanently write onto tags. however, i have never wrote permanently (just in case)

Question: Can it charge itself in sun and also charge the attached devices (assuming there is some charge left) at the same time, without requiring any switch?
Answer: It can, I fully charged an iPhone 4S three times while on a hiking trip in the Adirondacks NY. Make sure it's fully charged before you leave and let the solar power maintain the internal battery between charges. As I read before I bought this item it would take a few days to fully charge via solar only.

Question: How long does it take for the solar to charge the internal batteries from empty to full?
Answer: You can calculate it based on the specs. For the 7200mAh, the max input is 180mA for solar; therefore, 7200 divided by 180 = 40 hours of peak solar charging. Max input for plugin is 1000mA, so that equals 7.2 hours of plugin. For the 10,000mAh, the solar input is 200mA = 50 hours of peak solar charging & plugin input of 1500mA equals 6.7 hours plugin. If lighting is not at full light, solar could take even longer time.

Question: Ive read that headphones don't fit through the case, is this still true or has this been fixed? Is there a different style you have that allows this?
Answer: Thank you for your question. All of our cases are designed to be compatible with the earphones with the standard male 3.5mm output such as Apple EarPods, Samsung stock earphones, beats by Dr Dre, Skull Candy, etc. However, the compatibility will also depend on how thick the mold or shielding of the output is. Question: It will not fit in the case at all...what should I do?
Answer: Rebecca...first place the soft rubber skin on the phone by snapping two opposite corners over the corners of the phone, then stretch the other two corners over the phone one at a time. Adjust the cover for a good consistent fit. Then snap the hard plastic back over the back of the soft rubber skin, you will need to press the middle of each side from behind until the edges snap in. As before, once it is on you can adjust to have all of the features aligned between the two parts of the cover. Also important - when you place the phone into the holster the face of the phone should be pointing inward toward the holster. You can do it!

Question: What is the better buy? The 2nd gen 9000 or the 3E, outside of the fact you get an extra 1000mAh?
Answer: I'd go for this one over the 3E. The 3E is good, but it's a lot older. No shake to wake, charge ports top out at 2 A (this one is 2.4 max) so it's slower for devices that can take higher current. The charge display is also 4 LEDs, not 10 like this one. I had some 4 LED display batteries and I can tell you that those extra LEDs really help- they give you a much clearer idea of how much power is left (especially if it's one of the higher capacity packs, like the Astro E5). With the old 4 light display, when it gets to 25% you see one light lit... same as when it's at 1%. 25% is quite a bit of juice on something like the E5 (15,000 mAh) but 1% isn't on anything, and the thing is you can't tell which it is. The 2nd gen Astros can show you all the way down to 10% granularity which is a whole lot better.

Question: How do I turn off the Rav? Also, if it decides to not trickle my Moto X, do I need to remember to turn on the rav? Just how smart are these qi things in current management?
Answer: If the Rav is plugged into a power supply it is "on", and will charge a device with the appropriate receiver. When the device is charged, the Rav will still be on, but will cease charging the device. When the Rav is unplugged, drawing from its internal battery to charge your device, you need to turn it "on". Once on, it will remain on until your device is charged, it will turn off when your device is fully charged. It will also turn off after some set duration (I believe about 2 min) when there is no "draw" on the battery, so you can't waste its battery accidentally. I've been very happy with mine.

Question: Can this be taken on an Airplane
Answer: There are many new IATA rules regarding the transportation of large lithium ion/polymer battery packs, and they may also vary between countries (USA versus other countries and different airlines (see web sites below). Your PowerAdd battery back is rated at 32000 mAh which is therefore 32 x 3.7 = 118.4 Wh which is above the 100 Wh limit. For larger (> 100 to < 160 Wh) battery packs you MAY have to obtain permission from the airline to take up to 2 of them as spares on-board (ONLY permitted as carry-on, not checked-in), you should also package them according to the IATA guidelines (in their original box with electrical tape-sealed input/output ports to prevent a short circuit), and MAY also request you to present a safety sheet for the UN standards (see web pages below). I don't know whether or not this company (PowerAdd) has performed these tests and will supply you with the safety test sheet (see below where I have found few companies I contacted would provide me with this safety sheet for their lithium ion/polymer batteries. Lithium Ion/Polymer Batteries allowed on Airlines, packaging and taping the inputs/outputs, AND VERY IMPORTANTLY THE NEW REGULATIONS FOR THE UN MANUAL OF TEST CRITERIA PART III SUBSECTION 38.3 AND DROP TEST IATA DGR 49: UPDATE: HERE IS THE IATA 2015 GUIDANCE DOCUMENT: SEE SECTION 2.3.4.7 FOR THE TRANSPORTATION OF LARGE (> 100 WH AND < 160 WH) LITHIUM ION/POLYMER BATTERIES: http://www.iata.org/whatwedo/cargo/dgr/Documents/lithium-battery-guidance-document-2015-en.pdf Flights in the USA http://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ash/ash_programs/hazmat/passenger_info/media/faa_airline_passengers_and_batteries.pdf British Airlines: http://www.britishairways.com/cms/global/pdfs/lithium_battery.pdf Cathay Pacific: http://www.cathaypacific.com/cx/en_HK/travel-information/baggage/restricted-items/batteries.html Spare Lithium Battery Protection: http://safetravel.dot.gov/tips.html IATA Updated Lithium Ion Passenger Sheet: http://www.iata.org/whatwedo/cargo/dgr/Documents/passenger-lithium-battery.pdf IATA Fuller Sheet on Lithium Ion/Polymer Batteries: http://www.iata.org/whatwedo/cargo/dgr/Documents/Lithium-Battery-Guidance-2014.pdf UN Manual of Test and Criteria Part III Subsection 38.3: http://www.kta-ev.com/v/vspfiles/assets/images/intertek-un-lithium-ion-batteries-transportation.pdf VERY IMPORTANTLY, the airline MAY require the passenger to obtain permission before taking on-board a lithium ion battery of > 100 Wh and < 160 Wh capacities (only allowed as carry on except for some medical devices), with protection from damage (in original packaging with the input and output plugs taped, and with a copy of the UN Manual of Test and Criteria Part III Subsection 38.3 (Test T1 to T8) and Drop Test IATA DGR 49 sheet showing that the battery passed all of those tests. I have found that lithium ion/polymer battery suppliers are reluctant to provide you with this sheet or have not tested their batteries to this standard. Anker told me they could not give me this test sheet for their 20000 mAh (74 Wh) Astro Pro 2 Gen 1 battery, Goal Zero were testing their 100 Wh Sherpa 100 battery pack but a company correspondent told me that they would not provide me with the test sheet, while BIxPower immediately provided me with their fully detailed and successful UN Manual of Test and Criteria Part III Subsection 38.3 and Drop Test IATA DGR 49 sheet for their BixPower BP 160 (153 Wh) lithium ion battery pack, and which was signed by the Engineering Manager! This company (BixPower) was the only one I found at that time who was prepared to comply with the IATA and provide such a safety sheet for these tests: 1) T1 Altitude 2) T2 Thermal Cycling 3) T3 Vibration 4) T4 Shock 5) T5 External Short Circuit 6) T6 Impact 7) T7 Overcharge 8) T8 Forced Discharge And B: Drop Test IATA DGR 49 I believe that the latter test sheets may be increasingly requested by airlines to prevent inexpensive, poorly manufactered, and therefore potential dangerous large lithium ion/polymer batteries being transported, and I would not wish to be denied permission to transport a lithium ion/polymer battery or, worse still, get prosecuted due to transporting a large lithium ion/polymer battery on an airline which inadvertently caught fire without also having a copy of the PASSED UN test safety sheet for that particular battery. In conclusion, I believe that it is very important for yourself and fellow passengers to strictly comply with the IATA and airline safety rules regarding these batteries and ensure that you buy safe batteries which have sucessfully passed all of the appropriate safety tests for which the UN Tests safety sheet is provided.

Question: I have an ASUS Gamers Republic 17" with input of 19.5v "Would this be able to charge this beast of a laptop? It is akin to Alienware type laptop.
Answer: It should be able to. It won't power it when it is gaming, but if you're web-browsing or just doing general productivity tasks you should be set. I have a custom build but it is based off of a Clevo W350ST, which isn't anything particularly powerful, but it has a GTX 765M. This battery runs flawlessly when it only uses the integrated graphics. Honestly, I would not expect it to run fantastic if your computer does not have graphics switching, but I would think it would have switching, as it is a very power intensive and high-end computer. The reason I would expect it not to run well with the graphics card on is that your computer could temporarily have spike processor usage that could switch off the battery. For instance, chrome and outlook are opened at the same time requiring more power, but the battery is close to its current limit already. I also have a Turcom battery, but I feel that this is the better built and functioning product for barely any difference in price. Hope this helps.

Question: I've heard that magnets aren't good for computers. Has anyone had any issues with their computers from carrying them in a magnetic case?

Question: Does the Matrix2 offer multipoint support? In other words, can I connect (via) to my tablet and phone at the same time?
Answer: Just to clarify, the Matrix2 does not offer multipoint support. It seems that this feature was not added when they upgraded from Matrix to Matrix2. That said, I confirmed with a technician at MEEElectronics that you can simultaneously connect one device by Bluetooth and another by hardwire. For example, I wanted headphones that would allow me to watch videos on my laptop while also notifying me of any incoming phone calls. This can be accomplished by connecting to my laptop via Bluetooth and to my smartphone using the cable that's included. Hope this helps.

Question: I see people say these sound good but can we get more information on how good they sound. How do they compare to other known headphones $300 and under
Answer: They sound terrific. I love the sound of these better than my wired V-Moda headphones but there is a known issue with phone calls constantly disconnecting and re-connecting. The manufacturer is aware of it and recommended the earlier version if I wanted to have functional bluetooth phone calls but the earlier model has more bass. I enjoy the sound so much that when a call comes in, I prefer to plug in a cable if the call is going to last more than 2 to 3 minutes which is when the bluetooth connection starts to drop.

Question: is there a warrantee?
Answer: Yes. Mine broke so I contacted the seller and they sent me new ones.

Question: Does this fit over (not on) your ears?
Answer: It would depend on the size of your ears. For most people it fits over, not on.

Question: Is there a way to use it on devices without bluetooth connectivity? I mean a TV for example. (and without using the cable as well).
Answer: The only way to use these headphones is through the bluetooth or the provided cable. But you can get a Bluetooth transmitter and hook it through your tv or stereo to work with the headphones. I did this and watch movies while I work. I have been very happy with this solution. Highly recommended.

Question: I mostly listen to EDM, rap, hip hop, dubstep, etc. Is the overall listening experience for these headphones better than Beats especially with bass?
Answer: I haven't listened to Beats a lot - I tried them in the store and wasn't impressed, esp given the price... So it's hard to say if these are better, I wouldn't say they are worse and certainly don't have any complaints about the sound quality for the price - I listen to a lot of EDM as well. They can be a little uncomfortable after a while, the ear pads are a little thin and they actually rest on my ears even though my ears are completely covered.

Question: Are this headphone OEM version of this Nakamichi BT304? http://www.amazon.com/Nakamichi-Over-...
Answer: I have the Nakamichi and wondered the same. They certainly look almost identical except for the carbon fiber accents on the Matrix2. Spec wise though the Matrix are bluetooth 4.0 with aptX etc. and the Nakamichi are 3.0 so they look like more of a twin with the Meelectronics Venture. In addition Nakamichi's website has a new version that is Bluetooth 4.0 but doesn't mention aptX.

Question: what type of battery do these headphones have ?? how is it recharged, and is it replaceable without having to send them to the shop ?? Thanks
Answer: The battery is not replacable - at least it's not accessible in anyway that I can see. I understood when I bought it that once the rechargeable battery stops charging, it's time for a new headset. It is charged by plugging it in to any USB port. In my opinion these are great headphones for the price. Even though I'll have to replace it eventually (3-4 years??) I could buy 4+ of these for what I'd pay for other headphones. They're not noise cancelling but the sound quality is excellent.

Question: Do these headphones have anything boosted (bass, treble?) I'm looking to use them for DJing and watching movies .
Answer: No, the settings are not programable. They do sound great for streaming music off Pandora and great for movies off of my laptop with no lag in sound. Not so sure if they would work well for DJing.

Question: In terms of the sound quality, speakers, and audio reproduction only (not the other features), how do these compare to the brand's Venture headphones?
Answer: I strongly believe "you get what you pay for". I've had a few headphones that were <$100. They were okay and it was all I could afford. I upgraded to Bose (@$350). I loved them but they were bulky, I hated the wire, and they were hard to pack for flights because the case was big. The MEElectronics wireless have been great for me. Terrific sound, light weight, and the cost was affordable. If it was me, and I had the extra $50, I'd go for the Air-Fi Matrix vs. the Venture

Question: Does it support HFP, so you can just tell Siri to dial a number or play music for you?

Most times expect to have to use it a couple times unsuccessfully before you get a successful use. Also, while using navigation you'll get cut off instructions from Siri turn by turn. I get around this by playing Spotify, Pandora, Music, etc. while using GPS. It seems having that playing stops the cut off audio issue. Not sure if it's a Bluetooth issue or a software issue.

Question: How do you correctly charge this device? I charged it over night and it is not charging my phone still.
Answer: When you plug it in to charge, you must press the button to the right of the 25. Then the 25 will glow solid. This means it's charging your phone. Once your phone is 100% it will switch and charge the battery backup device (and the numbers will blink). Once the backup battery is done charging itself, it doesn't switch back to charging to phone. I think this is a design flaw. So if you don't press that button when you plug it in, it only charges the backup battery device.

Question: I charged my case for more than 10 hours, but it's not working!! It doesn't turn on when I plug in the Iphone. I think it's broken =(
Answer: Have you tried hitting the power button located in the lower right hand corner right next to the number "25"? Yes, that's a button, it pushes in and *clicks* which turns it on or off. You can turn it off and use your iPhone battery or you can turn it on and recharge your iPhone. While plugged in, pushing the power button to turn the battery case off redirects electricity directly to your iPhone charging it and pushing it again will redirect electricity to charge the case's battery and disconnects from the iPhone. Also, the amount of time that it takes to charge depends on your charger block. If you're using a USB 2.0 port, it's only pushing out 500mA, which will take 8 to 10 hours to charge, while using a 1000mA charging block, which comes standard with the iPhone lightning connector can charge your battery in half that time. It takes 4 to 5 hours to fully charge my battery case using Apple's standard 1000mA charging block.

Question: I purchased my mount back in February. It has worked wonderfully. Yesterday the neck snapped off while driving. Any chance of a warranty?
Answer: Doubt it, this is a design flaw. Read my review. I really wanted to love this device but they should have used metal instead of plastic at the stress point. You can Super Glue this together, not a great option but I did it to mine and it's holding so far. I used a gel type super glue, figured it would handle vibrations better. So far it's held for 4 months. I would however recommend to anyone buying this to carefully take the little screws out (VERY CAREFULLY), and putting a few drops of super glue under the connection and replacing the screws. The weak point is the screw housing tubes, they are plastic and will eventually break. I figure that if you glue before it breaks, it will relieve the stress on the plastic.

Question: I have read some reviews which indicate that the phone shakes in the mount when driving even on smooth roads. Anyone else experience this?
Answer: Hi, nope, so far no shaking, when you slide the flat part into the CD player, there is a knob that you turn on the bottom, and it locks the phone holder in very tight, so there is no shaking. I drive on the highway daily and I don't notice any shaking of the phone

Question: Does it hold a HTC One?

Answer: It holds a full charge for a long, long time. I had it in the bottom of my purse for well over a month or more, fully charged, and when I turned it on like 4-6 weeks later? STILL FULLY CHARGED! I was amazed to say the least.

Question: Can I charge my Kindle Fire?
Answer: Yes, it will work for the Kindle Fire. It comes with an USB cable that has a combo MicroUSB/Apple 30-pin connector on the one end.

Question: will this charger also work with an ASUS 300 tablet?
Answer: This bat pack had 2usb slots to charge stuff. It also has a short cord that charges most Android phones.

Question: How long will the charger hold its charge without recharging?
Answer: I haven't had mine long enough to tell but anecdotal observations indicate that the batteries/unit seem to follow the "standard" Lithium discharge rate of 5-10% a month. Wikipedia and Google can lead you to more "in depth" analysis if you want......I find it helpful to just think of it as a big cell phone battery (can I leave my cell phone off for a month and turn it on etc). The key to storage is temperature (cooler is better then warm), you really start to digress into the more "in depth" stuff as soon as you ask the question :0 Sorry if that is not specific enough I tried to explain "it depends". Overall I have found the unit/device to be of high quality and am unsure as to what an $80 10400mah battery would offer over this one. There very well may be nuance's but for the average and above average user you won't be able to tell the difference.

Question: Is it for android phones? Can it charge the battery in one single charge? Does it need a USB connector to it?
Answer: Yes, it is for android phones. I have a droid phone. No, it doesn't need a USB connection. A charging cord is nicely wrapped around the phone and for other types of phones such as an iphone, a charging cord comes with it. It charges the battery quickly. I am loving it!

Question: Does the velcro really secure the phone to your arm - even if you are doing higher intensity exercise such as running?
Answer: Yes. The wrist band holds very well. The velcro connection between the case and the wristband holds very well. I ran into issue where the adhesive between the velcro patch and the case came unglued when I was pulling the case from the band. I believe this was due to moisture while I was running. I don't believe it would have detached during the run, but seems that at times the velcro hold could be stronger than the adhesive hold and you will need to be careful when pulling apart. Otherwise, the holds are very strong.

Question: Could I use it with a Lifeproof case on my iPhone 5s?

Question: Is it easy to pull off mid run to change a song or something and reapply without slowing down?

Question: Does this work with the IPod Touch 5th Generation?

Question: Will this work for a Samsung Galaxy 3G?

Question: Is the sound loud enough for a car?

Question: Any beeping?

Question: Does this speaker have a loud tone/voice saying "Ready/Connected/Not Connected" or is it just a light? If there is sound, can it be disabled?

Question: What is the difference between this model and the B009N1RV9U?
Answer: This one is bigger but lighter, and has bluetooth 4.0. I compare its sound to the one coming out from a mobile phone speaker. No bass, and as loud as a mobile phone. The B009N1RV9U is smaller, heavier and has an older bluetooth version, but it sounds 3 time better than the newer version, a lot louder and has bass. I recommend the B009N1RV9U.

Question: can you use it with a tv that don't have blue tooth
Answer: dont see why not as long as the tv has an audio out then i think you can use the stereo jack provided and just hard wire the tv to the speaker.

Question: I'm seeking a device that can work in a conference room with 8-12 people around it, running off a laptop; can I select the specific b/t device?

Question: How can the battery be charged besides using a PC USB slot?

Question: how long does it take to charge? i broke the LEDS and cant tell by them. Also will the battery over charge?
Answer: It takes about 20 minutes

Question: What and when is the sound it makes
Answer: It beeps each time charging starts (that is, you get the phone lined up on the charging pad.) However, with the wireless receiver that I have for the Galaxy Note 3, when its fully charged, it stops taking power and the charging pad disconnects. For some number of minutes, and then it decides to start charging again, and another beep. It gets annoying after a while. There is an LED that changes from green to blue when the charging pad and receiver in the phone sync up, so the sound isn't necessary. I opened mine up, and the small "speaker" is not easy to disconnect as it is a surface-mount device, soldered directly to the printed circuit board; there are no wires to easily cut. However, as I happen to have a hot air surface mount solder rework station, I just took the speaker part off the board and now have sweet silence. If you try this, make sure to use low air flow, as there is a 0603 sized capacitor component that I managed to blow off the board while removing the speaker, and I had to solder it back on the board.

Question: I have a Samsung Note II in an Otterbox Defender case. Anyone know if this charger will work?
Answer: Works well with my Samsung S4 in the otterbox defender case

Question: Do you need it perfectly aligned, or just roughly centered will do? Does anyone have this working with an Otterbox Commuter case?
Answer: I use mine with my Droid Maxx inside a Trident Cyclops case (which is similar to an Otterbox Commuter), and I haven't had any issues with it. There's a "sweet spot" you will find, what I do is lay it about 2" back, then slowly push it up until you hear the beep and the light turns blue. Also, if you have problems with slippage (fumbling in the dark, your cat is a jerk, etc.), try putting two or three small blobs of RTV silicone on the charger. Depending on the cure time, you can have it done by nightfall (or the next time you use it), it will give you extra slip resistance to keep your phone from sliding off the charger AND it won't interfere with the charge process.

Question: How many Amp is this Koolpad? This info should be standard specs info but I don't see it anywhere.
Answer: Input is good up to 2.1A while the output is 500-700mA.

Question: can you charge more than one phone on this charger? or does anyone know if there is a charging pad that can charge more than one phone?
Answer: You can only charge one Qi enabled phone on a koolpad Qi charger at a time.

Question: Where can I find operating instruction . There was nothing in the package to describe its operation
Answer: I looked at the picture. Make sure you bend back the paper on the battery contact points otherwise it doesn't work.

Question: I see a cross out on the speaker icon. Are you saying this is a silent version?

Question: Does this pad really keep the phone cooler than other pads? Or if you only bought this one, do you notice the phone getting particularly hot?

Question: Can anyone provide dimensions? They frustratingly do not list it anywhere, and I want to see if this is thin enough to fit in a car cradle.
Answer: My Qi charger, bought about four months ago, is 10 mm thick, 148 mm long, and 80 mm wide. And it works great, too. Very happy with it. I do note that the one in the picture has a different decal on the top. Mine has a stylized "qi" logo, but is labeled "Koolpad". So, I cannot guarantee that they have not changed the design. It is listed on the back as the model T-100. I use it to charge a Nexus 7 -2 tablet, also bought about four months ago. There is no problem with matching the "sweet spots" on both the charger and the tablet to get a good connection, even though the tablet is considerably larger than the charger.

Question: I heard "Network reception is a big flaw" It juggles between 3G & 2G & u need to restart to get network. Is this correct ?
Answer: In the US it will only work on 2G or EDGE network. ATT is degrading its 2G network. However T-Mobile s network is working well. Look at the Bands they work on. 3G or HDSPA require 1900Mhz freq. The P780 is 2100Mhz on 3G so it isn't compatible in the US. Look at the Lenovo K900 as it works on US networks very high speed HDSPA+ almost 4G or LTE speeds. I have both the P780 & the K900. T-Mobile on the P780 for 2G. The K900, AT&T HDSPA+ very fast. Hope that helps

Question: If I hook up these speakers via USB, can volume still be controlled by the computer or it needs to be controlled with the knob on the back of the speaker?
Answer: Yes. Set the speaker volume then use your computer output volume. They even power down when you shut the computer off.

Question: I like these speakers, but I already have a DAC; is hooking up these speakers (with their built-in- DAC) to a system with a DAC a problem?
Answer: If you use your existing DAC to send sound to the speakers, then you will input into the speakers with analog red/white RCAs, which will bypass the DAC inside the speakers. The internal DAC for these speakers is only accessed when you input signal via USB.

Question: Do you need a high end sound card to have the full advantage of these speakers or does it not make a difference sense its usb connected? Thanks.
Answer: From what I have read, better speakers would be a better investment before changing the sound card. Have a look at this forum. http://www.tomshardware.com/forum/58378-6-speakers-sound-card

Question: These or Bose Companion 3? Thanks
Answer: I've developed a distrust for name brands, so on that sentiment alone, I'd go with the Audioengines. I can say from experience, though, that the A2+'s are amazing. They lack a little bit of bass, but that's to be expected, and I'm sure the Bose's would suck in that regard as well. Go with the Audioengines.

Question: A2 vs Klipsch pro media 2.1? also does this A2 need a sub woofer?
Answer: Well, you asked the right person, since I own and use both. While I love Klipsch generally, and regard it as overall the top value brand, (5.1 home theater, etc.) I was really blown away by the performance of the A2+. The only handicap I have in answering you is I've used the A2 with a sub controlled by an inexpensive but wonderful preamp (the gemini pa-7000) since day one. But this is revealing-- I had to reduce the crossover to only 80 cycles -- that's real speaker territory. So, I'd call the addition of a sub a nice add-on but far from necessary. If anything, I find these little guys a bit bassy if anything. Naturally, a lot depends on your environment. Mine's a kitchen -- very flattering acoustically. Bottom line is the A2+ is more the 'real deal' since you have the option juice it up, making it a 'system,' later. There's no hint of being 'just a computer speaker.' Overall, while I like my 2.1's fine, I love my A2s.

Question: These don't come with a remote (for volume). Can you purchase one separately?
Answer: I don't think you can have a separate remote to control the volume for these... but rather you can buy a bluetooth audio receiver and hook it in and wirelessly stream audio to the speakers. Audio engine has a wireless transmitter and receiver but thats 150$. You can buy a belkin one for 20$ and it works perfectly for me.

Question: How would you integrate a subwoofer into the system along with these speakers if your source just has RCA outputs and a line-out as 3.5mm?
Answer: Dear Ian, Thank you for your question. The A2+ Premium has added a 3.5mmm variable output connection. Simply using a standard iPod connection cable (3.5mm to RCA left/right) will allow you to connect to a powered subwoofer. Please let me know if I can answer any additional questions for you! Regards, Eric Cohen World Wide Stereo

Question: Would these speakers be okay for a record player setup? I know the 5's would be better but would these do the job?
Answer: I have the 5's in my home office and the 2's in my work office. Both are connected to the Audioengine sub and sound GREAT!!! Sound is personal and I like both setups that I have, but the 5's really bang, shake and sound incredible. The 2's are really good with my setup, but I can't really bring the house down at work.

Question: you can plug any subwoofer into these speakers right? I have an extra sub lying around that I want to use instead of buying the as8 subwoofer.

Question: How much bulk does it add to the phone? It shows .5" thick, which would almost double the thickness. Is that accurate?

This is due to a raised perimeter around the 'wallet pocket' that protects the phone and is incorporated into the plastic case. The wallet only holds three cards and I wouldn't suggest making this a primary use wallet as it is difficult to access. I keep a credit card, $20 bill, and gym ID and it works great.

Question: Once you've used the cover for awhile, do the cards/money fall out easily or do they stay secure? Others have a lip to keep the cards from falling out

That being said, it probably makes sense to keep more than a couple of cards (or bills) to make it thick enough for it to not be an issue. The case is holding up great! Thanks for asking. -SEAN

Question: Does charging stop when battery if 100% charged?
Answer: Yes. It works just like your wired charger (except it has no wires) with a few key differences: 1. Your phone limits the current received in this way (the limit is device manufacturer specific - my SG S4 will only take 700mA via its wireless charge port) 2. The QI wireless charging standard limits the max current to 1000mA. 3. The phone will charge fully (within the limits above), turning "off" the wireless charging port when done. The thing is, then the phone almost immediately starts to deplete the battery, and the charging resumes (speaking ONLY from experience with my device). The final net effect is your phone enters a "floating battery" state: the charger is powering your device, while your battery sits idle at 100%. I have left my S4 on the charging pad overnight many times, the same way i have left it in the wired charger overnight many times... same result either way - phone works just like it did previously, just the way i know it to work.

Question: Does this phone supports whatsapp?
Answer: The application exists on the phone under the Main Menu in a "Chat" subdirectory. I actually see three items: eBuddy IM, Chat, and WhatsApp. I must admit, however, that I have my internet disabled, and I just use this as an awsome pay-as-you-go "Voice Phone" to supplement my work's smartphone. I just wanted something small and easily to slip in my pocket to replace my failing E51 of MANY years. I picked this over the E52 largely because this is a new phone, and that is technology from 3 years ago which I'd have to buy from the Gray Market overseas. For voice calls, it's great. And the ringer gets CRAZY Loud. I do miss wi-fi though... and I'm too cheap to burn my pay-as-you-go minutes for internet. With internet off, and voice only it seems to hold a charge for about 24 days... and I've talked as long as 11 hours on it before the bar got down to 1/3 to 1/4th power. It beats the pants off of the "Disposable" TracPhones... and my HTC Sensation/Blackberry/Samsug Galaxy S for voice calls and ring volume. I can hear it from the other side of the house (Though I did set the electronic screeching of Skrillex "Boomerang" as my ring tone so it would be extremely audible!) Decent MP3 Player too. Camera is small in MegaPixel but the seamless Panaramic Patch-View mode that stitches together pictures by connecting invisible "floating boxes" works really well. Wish my high-end Digital Cameras did that!

Question: I bought this item.it is hard to figure out how to turn the power on , turn off, pairing, volume up and down, how to answer phone calls.can you send me the info ?
Answer: Power up: Hold the middle button down until you see light green flashes coming from the little light located over the "ON/OFF" text. To Pair: go to Bluetooth settings on your Iphone, it will search for this device, when found select connect. Mine is called "S9-HD" Volume up and down are the first and third buttons located on left and right (remember middle is power on/off) To power down hold the middle button down until red flashes. Question: Where are the styluses and their materials made? Do they need a Prop 65 warning on them for sales in CA?
Answer: Hi Storm Eagle! Thanks for your inquiry. Our company falls under the 'small business exception' clause in the Prop 65 and we are therefore exempt from the Prop 65 obligations. Nevertheless, we always strive to provide our customers with high quality products, consumer safety is one of our top priorities and we have extensive quality control procedures in place to ensure we live up to our own expectations. This is one of the main reasons we manage to maintain a 4-5 star rating for most of our products. These stylus pens are made in China; the pen is made of aluminum with an oxidized surface, and the tip is made out of silicone/rubber. I hope this helps! Question: has anyone had trouble pairing the device?

Question: Does it charge your galaxy devices relatively quickly like the original?
Answer: The cables I received could not. The Galaxy phones check that the metal portion of the micro-b plug body is conductive to the internal ground (meant to be through cable shielding, and these cables are not shielded), which is generally true only on higher quality cables. These cables do not have that conductivity, and so the phone will limit charging amperage to something less than 800 mA.

Question: Why does the four port cost more than the five port, shouldn't be the other way around?
Answer: Both the white and black color version of this charger have 5 ports. The black color charger costs more because it uses "smart ports" where each of the 5 ports can provide a charge at any device's maximum capability (for example, it can charge 5 iPads at once at full speed). On the white color charger, only certain ports will charge certain devices at full speed (for example, only 2 of the ports can charge the iPad at full speed).

Question: Will this charge the Anker E5.?
Answer: Yes it will. If you plug it into the "Android" port, you're getting ~the same current that your USB port on your computer provides. You can charge most any modern device (made since implementation of USB 2.0) through any of the ports. Plugging into one of the "iPad" ports may shorten your charging time significantly; it depends on how the E5 negotiates the charge current it draws. But, long story short, you should be able to plug just about any modern device into any of the ports on this charger and charge it as fast or faster than through your computer's USB port. I recommend using the "iPad" port to ensure that your device draws the maximum current it will accept to minimize charge time. Hope that helps!

Question: Samsung Galaxy S5 - we know it'll charge on 1A port, does it charge from 2.1A port ? that's the main point here.

Question: Can you verify the port holes for charging the kindle are on the opposite side of the camera? Wanting to make sure the case will line up properly on Kindle Fire HD 7" I have
Answer: If you bought your kindle fire HD after October 2013 and did not buy the previous generation then this case will not fit. The newest kindle fire HD has the charger port on the opposite side from a speaker. It is very streamlined with a micro usb port, a power button, a speaker port and a plus and a minus button. That is it. This case is made for Kindle Fire HD's produced prior to October 2013 and has a large flap/opening on one long side and then two round windows and a circular port opening on the other long side. It has a speaker opening, three buttons and a flap on the bottom short side and a speaker opening on the top short side. I know that is not that clear but hopefully it gives you enough information to make a decision.

Question: How do I get all of these bubbles out from under the screen cover??
Answer: Hello Heather, that has been the most aggravating situation for my kids as well as me. If you can find a frame shop that has gorilla glass they can replace it for you, however I have not been able to find one. You can also order gorilla glass online and either try it for yourself or have a professional glass company that deals in windshields try and do it for you. That is my next step. One other option that helps but you will still will have a little bubbles is place the top and your Kindle and a moist free dry environment and that will help a little. The best option though it's try and get that top replaced with gorilla glass. Good luck that is better trust me, I feel your pain and aggravation.

Question: is this case necessary for wireless charging the lumia 1020? If I dont buy this, and only but the dt-900 charger will it work?
Answer: The 1020 cant communicate with the dt-900 without the wireless charging cover. If you look on the back of your Nokia 1020, you will notice two small circular openings near the bottom. The wireless charging cover has two prongs that actually insert into those openings when you put the cover on. In any case, this is how the cover adds in the functionality to use the NFC feature to wirelessly charge the phone. I know that was a long answer, but the short answer is "YES the case is necessary for wirelessly charging the Lumia 1020".

Question: does it include the charger or only the case?
Answer: The CC-3066 is packaged with the snap on back and no other items. The charger/induction plate combination is available separately.

Question: Can you add an additional cover over the case ? Will it still charge with a case over it to protect the phone?
Answer: The charging cover and the charging base seem to be engineered to pretty precise specs. The charging cover is thin and permits charging to full charge in the same time as a direct wire charge. If I were going to consider a cover, "Otter" grade, I would have to give up on transduced charging. I enjoy the convenience of charging during the day without the hassle direct wiring. Forget the cover and enjoy the charging system of the future or go for the cover and forget the advanced charging system that Nokia has created. The 1020 discharges faster that the iPhone 5 that I had. So always being charged up is a priority for me. When at my desk, my 1020 sets on the charge plate. No wires to fiddle with to charge my phone during the day. I never know when I will be away from a charging system, so being charged up is important to me. When I retire for the night, my phone is generally 100% charged up. The feeling of a charged up phone is important to me.

Question: Does it use BT 4.0 & Dolby Digital Plus like the new Jabra ROX? Thanks.
Answer: Even though it doesn't have BT 4.0, the benefits of 4.0 vs 3.0 do not impact sound quality from what I have read while researching bluetooth headphones. This is because streaming music is a high bandwidth activity and BT 4.0 improvements are in low energy low bandwidth applications. The Jaybird BlueBuds have excellent sound quality but run BT 2.1 + EDR. I'm wondering if it effects standby time though, but I don't really care about that with bluetooth headphones. The sound quality comes more from the codec used (aptX or jaybird's Shift) and the quality of the headphone itself. This headphone has aptX and a balanced armature driver, which is a very good combination. I'd definitely test them both out and decide for myself which are better.

Question: why is it disconnected so often? Do I need to charge it up or.... ? I unboxed it and use it but after a day it disconnected very often.
Answer: I think i may have your answer, i have the same problem, but it happens because when you connect your Bluetooth headset to your phone, your WiFi disrupts the connection that it has made to you phone's network. I know because it happens to me, I do not use my WiFi with my Bluetooth headset, i have better strength and signal with my network. If i use my WIFI, it pops out sporadically, i think it is because the signal strength wavers, and therefore causing many disconnections, hope this helps...

Question: i bought the phone but the camera doesnt seem to work properly the focus is not working,can you help me guys fix that//?
Answer: first things first, be sure that it's in auto mode. There's also a manual focus mode. To check all your settings, simply swipe the shutter button up, you'll see the manual setting sliders. Check if the focus slider rests in auto mode. If it is not, slide all the way to your left, and leave it there. If this is not the case, check for the updates. First you gotta be sure that you're running the latest version of both the OS and the camera app. If no updates available, try to uninstall and install the camera app again. If nothing works, could be a hw problem. Let me know how it goes. Cheers.

Question: Will it jump start a car using the interior auxilary power outlet?
Answer: That cord is meant for recharging the unit not to jump start a car, You can not jump start any car that way with any product (only charge). The only thing you can do is do a slow low amp charge through the auxiliary power outlet ( I am a ASE certified tech and have seen people do much harm to the cars power outlet) Like others have said that outlet is fused and the biggest fuse I have seen is a 20 amp on that circuit, that is not enough amps to start a car.

Question: Anyone know how many AMPS this charger is? 12W yes, but at how many A?
Answer: 4.8 Amps total. 2.4 Amps per port. 2.4 Amps per port x 2 ports = 4.8 Amps. 12W x 2 = 24W 24W / 5V = 4.8A This unit is called reVOLT 12W + 12W by Scosche. So 24 Watts, not 12.

Question: How come this doesn't work with my Samsung Galaxy S 5? Even tried with the original cable that came with the phone.
Answer: You need a charge only cable. You can make one but just buy one. Do not use that cable to connect to your computer, though...may or may not short the computer's USB port. The unique feature of charge only cable is that the communication wires are severed and shorted together on the micro-USB end and left open circuited on the USB end. Your phone sends a signal out on one of the data wires and if the signal comes back, it accepts 2 amps. If it does not come back, it accepts around half that. The reason your Samsung Cable and wall charger work is because the wall chargers are wired that way so the cable needn't be a charge only cable. I have thus far been unable to find a cigarette lighter USB charger that has the data wires configured like a wall charger. So it is actually your phone that is limiting the charging rate at the moment. Pick up a charge only cable and you'll be all set.

Question: Why do you recommend total discharge every few months even though this a Lithium Ion battery and that it is not recommended for those batteries?
Answer: What I have found with lithium ion batteries is that when you don't drain the battery even few months even though they say you don't need to.. The battery becomes disproportionate in its charge. Letting it run all theway down allows it to evenly charge. I do it with all my devices. Just let them run out every few months and get a longer, better charge. Li-batteries normally have a strong life 2 to 3 years. My batteries average 4 to 6. And yes I use all of devices daily.

Question: This might be a stupid question but..........how do I recharge this battery?
Answer: You use the included orange USB cable to plug into any USB charger (like the one that came with your phone) or USB port on a computer/laptop. Question: Will this charge e-ink Kindles, like the basic model and the paperwhite?
Answer: Short answer = Yes, it will (I have the 1st gen Kindle touch with the e-ink screen and just plugged it in to verify for you). Longer answer = It'll charge faster than the stock Kindle charger because the stock charger's output is 500mA (.5 Amps) and this one has the 1 Amp (1000 mA) output and 2.4 Amp (2400 mA) output charge ports. Unsolicited advice = Don't do it. For two reasons- 1) If you look right above the charging port on the back of the Kindle, you should see "INPUT 5.25V MAX 500mA" meaning the maximum voltage rating for the Kindle's charging circuitry and battery type is 5.25 volts (standard USB output) and maximum current rating is .5 Amps- or HALF that of the lower power output of this charger- so there's a very real possibility that you could damage the Kindle. If you do damage it this way, Amazon most likely won't cover this damage under the warranty because it'll be obvious the circuitry was overloaded rather than failed as the result of a manufacturing flaw. 2) Power output and potentially damaged electronics aside, I can't recommend this charger. Whatever the hinge mechanism is inside this charger is apparently a very poor design. I've had it for maybe 3 weeks, folded and unfolded it POSSIBLY 8 or 9 times and the hinge is already lose enough that when plugged in, the slightest bump causes the charger to spark as the mechanism separates and re-contacts. At best, this is an annoyance because it means the charger could sit an an angle that keeps it from charging your device if the hinge never reconnects. At worst, it's a pretty significant fire hazard (I've stopped using mine and it's going in the garbage).
