Question: bought this tracker but where do i buy the sim card to make it work?
Answer: Cell Phones are required by US law to be able to call 911 without a SIM card. Whether the 911 Services know the GPS coordinates is dependant on the local capability of the 911 Response Center and the capabilities of the cell towers provided by the telecom service company. It is mandated by 2019 all 911 Dispatch centers, cell service providers, and cell phones transmit GPS coordinates during 911 calls in the United States. Currently if 911 is called in many location they will only triangulate location using cell towers. To serve as a location service to track people and geo bound them it would require a SIM card. I recommend in this case to buy a prepaid T-Mobile SIM card of $100 so that the minutes won't expire for a year. Until the total amount of minutes bought on T-Mobile prepaid add up to $100 the minutes expire in 3 months.

Question: Is there a way to reduce the pressure these use to wind the cord?
Answer: I will tell you my own personal fix. The spool is wound roughly nine or ten revolutions when it's made. If you loop a string or cable around the hook, you can let it revolve one or two turns, stop it with your finger and then gently remove the string. The pressure increases with every revolution, so this will reduce the pressure. Sometimes doing this means that i have to help the cord in the last few cm, but it's worth it for me. If you don't like the effect, you can always wind it up again by threading the string around the spool once, looping it onto the hook and pulling the spool around. Just make sure you don't over wind it, because that can damage it. You'll be able to feel the pressure building as you wind. Hope that helps!

Question: I have 2 boxes next to each other, TVs are in other rooms. Can I put two of these side by side do they have distinct RF channels?
Answer: Just to be sure I am understanding your configuration, you have two devices together you want to control from two separate remote locations. The extender itself doesn't have channels, but you don't need that. You get two of these extenders, but you only use one receiver at the location where you have the boxes. You have one sender with each remote TV location. Whichever sender you are using relays the remote commands to the receiver, the receiver relays the command to the box. If you are trying to allow the two different TV users/locations to control different boxes at the same time, (like one person is watching off the dvr in one room, someone else is watching the blu-ray in the other room) then you need a different extender brand from each location to its own receiver co-located with the boxes. Hope that answers your question.

Question: I have a Canon Optura XI and I just ordered this bundle. Now I realize it does not list my camcorder. Will these batteries work with an Optura XI?

I would anticipate that these batteries WILL NOT FIT, SO DON'T TEAR UP THE PACKAGE ANY MORE THAN YOU NEED TO! Once you've verified that the batteries don't work, get involved in the "return/refund" process. You might want to do this NOW, before actually receiving this package in the mail so you'll be able to act appropriately. I would not order any "universal replacement pieces" for any camcorder/camera, unless the original "advertisement" specifically mentions the parts will fit on your camcorder/camera model. If that information isn't there, the chances are BETTER THAT IT WON'T FIT/WORK, THAN THAT IT WILL. Hope this helps! Good Luck.

Question: I bought this unit because I thought it was a stand-alone range extender. Do I absolutely need to buy a base unit to make it functional?
Answer: Yes, you need what we call the base unit like (TP-LINK TL-PA211 AV200 Mini Powerline Adapter) . the base unit is the one you plug in the electricity outlet near your router and you connect it with the router by a RJ cable . after that you can plug the WPA281 (the one you already have it) in any electricity outlet in your home and you will have both Wifi signal plus a cable connection option.

Question: If I add this to my existing TP Powerline Network can I set it up to extend my already existing Wi-Fi network [not TP] or does it add its own Wi-Fi?

Question: I have clear that it uses US plugs, but the specification, it stats 110V only or 110-240V range?

Question: I have a TP-LINK TL-PA511 KIT Powerline Gigabit Adapter Starter Kit installed and it works great. Would this work with that model?
Answer: It should, but it will likely slow your network speed down to 300mbps. This shouldn't be a problem unless you REALLY need your home network to run at 500mbps.. You'll note I said should.... TP-LINK USA has very responsive and informative email help staff. For a definitive answer, I suggest you contact them at this address. support.usa@tp-link.com

Question: Do these powerline adapters come with a NZ/AU AC adapter? Thanks in advance!
Answer: No, no adapters for NZ/AU plugs. The powerline adapters have a US plug.

Question: Can I pair this to a TL-PA2010KIT AV200 NANO?
Answer: I don't believe so. You have a 200mbps non-wireless powerline network. The TL-WPA281 is a 300mbps wireless transmitter that is meant to be paired with a matching 300mbps "base" unit connected to the router. The one real drawback to this model is that it creates a completely separate wireless network in your house, with it's own addresses and password. It does not "clone" and seamlessly extend your existing wireless network. They have a model that does that, the TL-WPA4220KIT, but at the time I made my purchase, it wasn't available in the U.S. Your best bet is to contact TP-Link through their website http://www.tp-link.com/en/about/?categoryid=107 and ask them which wireless adapter would work with your existing equipment.

Question: Can this be used with an existing ethernet-only Actiontec Powerline system?
Answer: Depends on the speed of the Actiontec Powerline system. This is homeplug AV, if your Actiontec is 85 mb or slower it is Homeplug 1.0. HOmeplug 1.0 and homeplug AV are not very compatible though it MAY work, but it will be slow.

Question: what is the difference between the TL-WPA281 an the TL-WPA281 KIT ?
Answer: The kit comes with two units in it: TP-LINK TL-WPA281 KIT 300Mbps Wireless N Powerline Adapter Starter Kit, 2.4Ghz N300 Adapter + 200Mbps Adapter, 802.11b/g/n by TP-LINK. So you get the base unit and one extension, a really good deal as the extension unit is only an additional $18.

Question: Has anyone found a good, fingerprint proof screen protector for this camera? Ive only used ScreenPatronus in the past and have wondered about Clarivue
Answer: My opinion will be controversial, but I'll offer it anyway :) I've come to believe it makes no sense to pay a premium price for a high resolution screen and then cover it with optically inferior plastic. This is like investing big bucks in a beautiful sofa and then covering it with a sheet to protect it from those who might actually sit on it. I used to slap screen protectors on everything. Now I don't use them with anything. Protectors may have been useful when screens weren't very sharp or durable. But screen and glass technology has advanced greatly, making screen protectors unnecessary and even undesirable on modern devices. Unnecessary , because the tempered glass used on most screens these days is highly scratch resistant. Undesirable, because even the best screen protector degrades the underlying image more than do the micro-scratches that inevitably accumulate on any glass surface that's actively used. Screen protectors degrade faster and more noticeably with use, and dust or air bubbles become more pronounced. Transparency diminishes as the material absorbs and reacts to skin oil. Yet few replace their degrading screen protectors. Most of us just put up with the deteriorating clarity until we buy a new device. My advice: Don't downgrade your high-res screen with a plastic overlay that offers scant protection over what the raw glass itself can provide. Just be reasonably careful with your device, and enjoy all the clarity and resolution you paid for. Keep a microfiber cloth handy to wipe off fingerprints. One caveat: tempered glass is very tough -- until you damage it. You may breathe a sigh of relief after inspecting your device following an accidental drop, thinking nothing was damaged. And you may be less careful in the future, thinking your device is tougher than you thought. This would be a mistake. The shock of that first drop may have caused microscopic fractures in the crystalline structure of the glass that will make it more vulnerable to breakage later. Think of them as invisible fault lines. That's why, if you've ever dropped your phone or camera on a hard surface, or significantly scratched the glass, you should be more careful with it afterward, not less. Whether you can see it or not, the glass will be more brittle and susceptible to shattering on a subsequent, milder drop.

Question: Can I put a hosts file on it so I don't have to put one on each individual computer?

Question: I have another router on the network. With the factory firmware, can I disable WAN and DHCP server on this? Because I want the other router tohostonly
Answer: Yes, it's actually pretty easy with one caveat: when you change the IP or mask on the LAN settings tab for the router, you need to be sure everything else is where it needs to be. For all the other settings tabs, you can click Save and it'll tell you that you need to reboot to apply settings. But change the IP or mask on the LAN settings tab and you'll be forced to reboot. Also, if you're just setting this up like I did as the wireless component of an existing wired network (I have a D-link handling primary router duties and am using this for the wireless functionality alone), you'll want to just ignore the WAN setup (and the WAN port on the back). Just plug into one of the 4 main LAN ports and connect that to your existing router, disable DHCP and set the IP address under the LAN settings for the router with the appropriate mask. Once you're forced to reboot the device, you'll just connect via your browser to that IP address you set. In my setup I picked an IP and set it up as a reserved IP for that device in my existing router to avoid conflicts (say after a power outage). After that you can set up anything else (wireless, etc.) unless you already did that before the reboot. Found this documentation: http://www.tp-link.com/en/article/?faqid=417 Also if you want to use it to extend an existing wireless network via WDS: http://www.tp-link.com/en/article/?faqid=440

Question: How to make this thing quiet? It is not like huge noise, but this irritating sound is a headache to me.
Answer: It does not have a hard drive. Mine is very quiet. The only part that would make any sound is the fan. I Googled "ct14-ao fan noise" and it led me to Google for "Vizio CT15-A1 Fan Issue" and it takes me to another entry in that same forum.notebookreview.com forum and the 5th response offers a quick fix, to go to control panel>power options>change plan settings>change advanced plan settings and change the maximum state to under 100% to inhibit the cpu turbo mode. Even though the CT14 does not have Turbo mode, slowing down the CPU will keep it from generating so much heat and should make the fan from running so fast or so often.

Question: Does this utilize EFI or BIOS? I'm thinking BIOS because of it's age, and Win7, but i want to run Linux instead of Windows.
Answer: You can boot into the familiar blue on gray American Megatrends (2011) BIOS (some variation or other of which I've been using for the past 25 years or so lol) by hitting the F2 key when the Vizio graphic displays on power-up (hitting the DEL key gets you to a DOS level boot options screen, where you see a Windows 7 choice, and at which point you can also choose to go into the more traditional F8 boot options if you wish ...like Safe Boot, for example). Interestingly though, in the BIOS boot option section, there's a UEFI boot choice, I'd never noticed before. So, I reset Boot Option 1 to UEFI, restarted ...and all that you could do - still - was go into BIOS, go to the boot option choice screen, or go directly to the Windows start up screen. So. No pretty UEFI to play with. Great question though.

Question: The keyboard on this machine does not have "Page up", "Page down", "Home", and "End" keys. Are there alternate key strokes/shortcuts to replace the function of these keys?

I more-or-less stumbled across that lol (actually, I think it's pretty standard for smaller laptops with keyboards sans those keys, but I'd long ago forgotten).

Question: Do you view what the camera sees on your GPS?

In order to ensure compatibility, check to make sure that your factory or aftermarket radio has an RCA video input jack. More likely than not any aftermarket radio with display will have one, but often times factory radios are a bit more tricky.

Question: will this camera be compatible with a WIFI sending unit or a wireless sending unit?

I can't say for sure without knowing the unit, but if it has a "composite" video input, there's no reason it should not work with this camera. Other than supplying power to the transmitter, receiver, and camera, you just have to be sure the car has a way to sense when it's in "reverse".

Question: What is the voltage for this camera? Will it work to replace the factory camera in my 2004 toyota 4runner with jbl and nav?
Answer: This camera most certainly required 12v. Most vehicle harnesses use 12v also but some use 6v. Just google to verify it uses 12v as well and that it uses the same connection type. Some vehicles have camera harnesses that are not the typical RCA. In that case you could always patch the power to your reverse light (also 12v) and the video signal patched into your factory harness to get it to your radio.

Question: How do I remove the mirror image to use the camera on the front?

However if you buy a made-for-cars monitor display you may find the monitor can be configured to switch the image, in which case the picture reverts the normal. After trying maybe a dozen different made-for-car cameras I gave up and bought an HD camera like the Go Pro. This gave a much more satisfactory picture under a wider range of condition. This particular camera failed after six hours of use.

Question: How does the lifetime warranty work?

Question: I am replacing a Seagate 750 GB Serial ATA 2 hard drive with this in a Dell XPS 435T. Will it work and do I need a new SATA cable? Thanks.
Answer: I will answer with a question of my own- what do you mean by "work" ? It will work in the sense that if you plug it in, the new 1TB will spin up and you can use it as you normally would. BUT, it will NOT work at the SATA III data rate that the WD supports (6Gb/s). The reason is, the motherboard (MOBO) in the Dell does not support SATA III, only SATA II. So instead, the WD will spin at the SATA II data rate, which is 3Gb/s. As for cable- the WD does not come with a cable so you will need a new one if you do not plan on reusing the one from the Seagate. However, if you reused the Seagate cable, you should be just fine since I would expect the existing cable is already rated to run at SATA II speeds. But if in the future you got a new MOBO or computer then you would need a new cable that is rated for SATA III data rates.

Question: Understand it fits d3xxx, d5xxx I have a few places I can buy older Nikon film camera lenses. Is there a list of lens mounts this fits? Interested.
Answer: This adapter allows you to attach to a standard 'T-mount' threaded connection to the Nikon proprietary lens mount. So any lens (or other component) threaded with a 42 mm diameter, 0.75 mm thread pitch can be attached. In theory you can mount any camera body to any lens as long as the T-mount adapters are available for the specific camera body and lens. Wikipedia has a good explanation of the T-mount if you are unfamiliar with them a thttp://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-mount.

Question: kit lens vs 18-135? Anyone have insight if the 18-135 really is worth the price difference?
Answer: It's not so much the IS as the "STM" or stepping motor used inside this lens vs. the USM motor used in their other high quality lenses. The USM is built to bring subjects into focus with bullet speed. That's great for still image (sports, auto racing, etc) photography but not so good for video where you want a slightly smoother transition when focusing between subjects. The STM motor is designed to work with the new Hybrid CMOS sensor in the camera that utilizes both contrast and phase detect focusing technologies, with the phase detect being the new addition. The STM motor is also stated to be quieter which should translate into less in camera noise being picked up in your videos. Basically once the camera is set into video mode the camera uses the phase detect AF system to get the camera very close to 100% focus lock and then switches over to contrast detect for 100% lock. This of course all happens in nanoseconds. At least this is what I've been able to gleam from the numerous preview articles I've read today. Hope this helps somewhat. FWIW, I'd be looking to get the 18-135 STM kit when/if I do decide to upgrade from my Rebel XT (yes, same camera for 7 years, can you believe it). The flexibility of the 18-135 focal range for all-around still shooting plus the video enhancements make it very appealing. At least as long as the IQ testing backs it up. Plus this lens was stated to sell for around $550 all by itself if I'm not mistaken so in the kit represents a great savings imo.

Question: How does the video quality compare to a standalone camcorder? I have a Canon VIXIA HF100 and would like to replace it with the T4i.
Answer: I have not used a stand alone camcorder but the picture quality on the T4i stood up to my husbands 46 inch big screen without any distortion or issues. There are various settings on this camera regarding the video quality you can use a higher storage capacity to get more footage with a higher quality but if you do that I would highly recommend investing in a battery grip for twice the battery life, although I have never had any issues with mine taking whatever it was being used for the battery grip will give you twice the battery life of a standard battery on this camera. The battery grip holds 2 of the standard batteries for longer shooting or video time with your camera. I have enjoyed every aspect of this camera and plan on using it Thursday to record my Daughters graduation ceremony because it does really well in low lighting. I hope that helps sorry I couldn't give you an honest answer regarding the stand alone but if you do find it is better or worse I would love to hear back from you regarding it. I do know in a comparison of the T4i and the new T5i that the only real difference between them is the price and T3i is great, I bought one for my daughter as a graduation present and couldn't resist playing with it, but the video quality on the T4i was much better and the photo quality was higher. I did a lot of research before investing in my camera and I can honestly say it was time well spent because I truly do love my camera and everything it provides me with.

Question: microphone noise?

Question: I am using a( Canon EF-S 15-85 lens)- is this going to cause me to loose benafits of my new T4i over the new 18-135 lens.
Answer: The only think you will lose is the features in the new focusing system and the quietness of the new lens for video recording. In essence, when you have that lens on it will be the same as a T3i for focusing - but you get the benefit of the other features.

Question: What is the difference between EF-S 18-135mm f/3.5-5.6 IS STM Lens and (18-55mm IS II Lens plus 55-250mm )? I am novice. Which is a better buy at same price?
Answer: The new STM lens is an inch shorter and adds a zoom lock and instant manual-focus override to the older 18-135mm EF-S IS lens, however manual focus is electronic. The focus ring isn't connected to anything, and there is a tiny time delay between when you move the ring and the lens moving. Another huge improvement from the older 18-135mm EF-S IS is that the zoom range from 24mm to 18mm has been spread-out on the zoom ring, so it's much easier to set precise wide-angle framing. On the old lens, it was very cramped at the wide end.

Question: Nobody ever talks about the zoom.....beginner and I like to read about the zoom like 18x etc on the t4i
Answer: As mentioned, Zoom factor isn't really relevant for a camera where you can change lenses at will. For example, if you have an 18-55mm lens (55/18 = 3X zoom) and add a 55-250mm lens, you have a total zoom range of 250/18 or nearly 14X. Add a 10-22mm lens and now you now have a total zoom range of 250/10 or 25X. This combination, however, will give you views MUCH wider than any point and shoot camera. What matters with DSLRs is the 'focal length'.

Question: what i sthe difference betwen the IS 2 lense and ISTM lense?
Answer: They are both image stabilizing but the ISTM also has a pretty silent motor so that you don't hear it focusing during movie modes.

Question: I had the T2i before, but now i got the T4i, which is a nice upgrade. In the T2i there is a A-deep mode in the wheel, where is that option in the T4i? Can anyone let me know? Thanks!
Answer: Canon decided to remove the A-Dep mode from the T4i to make room for new modes on the dial. They claimed that A-Dep was very rarely used and pretty much obsolete for DSLRs. As a replacement for A-Dep, you can shoot in AV mode and vary the aperture setting with the dial in order to change the depth of field. You can also try 'shifting the program' in P mode using the dial to get a smaller or larger aperture to adjust the depth of field.

Question: Hello! Could you please describe more details about this item? Such as, is it completely working well? How about the len condition and warranty? THX
Answer: This is my first dslr, definitely wanted a canon EOS, just didn't know whether to get the T3i or T4i. After doing weeks of comparisons, and realizing I could get the touch screen T4i at about the same as the T3i during an after-xmas sale, I made the purchase. This is a lot of camera for a first time dslr person, who is intent of being 'auto-free' when shooting pix. I love the possibilities of this camera and amazed at the technology available to me to create artistic photos and not just run-of-the-mill pictures. For those that do want the auto features, this camera will do it all. The touch screen LCD is an added bonus. As for the lens, it's a pretty good kit-type lens, not a lot of fluctuation in quality between f-stops. It's something that will work for me til I become the dslr master I want to be. I will then add highe quality lenses to my bag of tricks. Battery power is very long, no complaints. Have not had the camera long, so no warranty issues. This camera is feature packed, whether in creative mode or auto mode, and makes it easy for beginners and experts alike to create some pretty special memories. I love this camera!

Question: can you get it with a 18-135 lens?; do other canon lenses fit from my old 35mm canon?
Answer: Yes, I see the T4i 18-135mm STM kit listed here and elsewhere. Old Canon FD mount lenses will not fit any Canon DSLRs. Old Canon EOS EF lenses will work with the T4i though some film-era 3rd party lenses may not be completely compatible. Note that the smaller sensor in the digital Rebels will crop the image from the lens and make it appear as if you are using a 1.6 times longer lens. For example, your old 50mm lens on the T4i will appear more like an 80mm would on your film SLR and 28mm and 35mm lenses won't be wide angle lenses when used on the T4i.

Question: Hi, how come the camera take 5 to 6 seconds to take a picture? Did I messed up something in settings? Thank you

You can control your exposure time in the Tv & M settings the simplest way is to utilize the back touch screen use the Q button to access touch control select the shutter speed its the top left corner if the number has a " those are full seconds if its a fraction well thats a fraction of a second generally with a camera this heavy I wouldn't use slower than 1/160 without a tripod. If you are using other settings try adjusting your aperture (F stop) & ISO they are the other 2 legs of your exposure triangle. You my want to check out some books about your camera "Canon 4TI /650D Experience" by Douglas J. Klostermann is a good start! Keep learning & explore your new camera!

Question: A reviewer says "most professionals would never use auto-focus". How would pro-shooter quickly switch from an object at 200ft to one that is at 10ft?

Question: how long does the film last? how should we store it if unused for 6+ months?

Question: Will this unit work with Windows 8 MS Street & Trips 2009?
Answer: I'm sorry. I cannot answer that as I have no knowledge of it. However, I can tell you that with Street Atlas there was a problem created with Windows 8/8.1 that appears to be related to a Windows update somehow. I don't have the particulars on that, but I do have some info. Yes, there is a fix. The problem occurs shortly after cranking up the GPS BU 353 s4 Antenna. Windows will eventually experience a Blue Screen of Death, go into an automatic reboot, and be just fine until you try to use that BU 353 s4 again. This same problem occurs with Windows Vista using the original BU 353. I'm told it also occurs with Windows 7, but I have no first hand knowledge of it. Anyway, there is a fix on the Delorme website for this. ****IMPORTANT***** Be sure that the BU 353 s4 GPS antenna is plugged in and nothing else when you go through the fix. The webpage for Delorme on this matter is titled "Troubleshooting the GlobalSat BU-353 GPS Receiver". If you do find a problem as described above with Windows 8 MS Street & Trips 2009 I'd suggest looking to see if that same fix applies and if it's not mentioned then give Delorme a call. They answer their phone M-F, 09:00 to 17:00 Eastern time. Another symptom is while the tracking is working and you're driving along all of a sudden you glance over at the screen only to find out you just drove the last ten miles of a 20 mile trip and you still have twenty miles to go. In other words, the antenna is working, but the tracking has frozen.

Question: Can you chart trips on a sailboat with this on my laptop say from New York to North Carolina?
Answer: I have used DeLorme Street Atlas before to mark where I dropped my crab pots and such and it worked great for that before I got a plotter for the boat. I suspect it would work, but for serious navigation I would highly recommend something with nautical charts, including depths, navigation markers, Etc. If you get stuck in the fog or nasty weather while boating you want something better than a street map.

Question: Does it require WiFi?

Question: I want to split the signal from XBOX One to TV and Samsung Laptop Monitor, will this work?

Question: How does it work with blue ray? Our TV only has one HDMI port which is connected to a Dish hopper. Can we switch from satellite TV to the blue ray without doing it manually with this device? I also have read about audio issues on these connectors ,has...
Answer: No, nsa, as Don A. says, this box takes the HDMI output from one device -- like your blu ray player, and splits it to send the signal to two TVs, not the other way around (choosing between two signal sources to feed one TV). When dealing with a HDMI signal, it does not matter the source (blu ray, DVD, game console, etc.); HDMI is a common type of communication between AV devices. What you are looking for will be called an HDMI switcher or switch box; most likely you will have to do something (push a button on the box, or on a remote) to select which signal gets fed to your TV.

Question: I need to replace old LNB's to my FTA satellite. Please tell me if it is going to work. Thank you. Also should I buy LNB brackets for these LNB's ?
Answer: so make sure you have the settings correct on your FTA satellite box for this LNB type, check your receiver manual if necessary. if not set correctly you will not get a quality signal. Since you are only replacing the LNB, you should have no problem with acquiring a signal, but also make sure you set the LNB to the correct skew. Best to use the "quality" signal scale on the receiver as you are moving it (the signal level just provides power info to the LMB and back not satellite signal power, so use the quality scale, they both work hand and hand but when you have a good high quality signal you will have the best capability for the system not to rain fade on you and have picture break up). Also move the LMB towards and away from the dish on the bracket to see if you can also get a better quality signal. Remember the signal change will take a little time to move so don't rush the movement of the LMB, do it slowly. Show Less

Question: Will this device allow caller ID info through to my remote phones so I can see who's calling on the handset?

Question: If a called is blocked you want how do you unblock it? My son calls and it blocks him...Thanks

Question: Will this device block calls if the caller has blocked his number?
Answer: If you have caller id service from your phone company, you probably have a feature you can enable called Anonymous Call Rejection. That feature will block any call that does not have a number associated with it. Then any call that comes through would have a number unless it is an "out of area" call. The T Lock, problems not withstanding, can block any number you put on the blacklist. Be aware of the following: Caller ID blocking ONLY WORKS FROM RESIDENCE TO RESIDENCE. Commercial users can retrieve your number with an ANI box even if you block your caller id. I got that surprise one day when a business I called for price and availability on a local number with my caller id blocked, called me back on my number to tell me that they found what I was looking for. What a shock and an education I got.

Question: Hi, what does it mean "Non-ECC CL11"? and Why other similar products does not say that?
Answer: "Short for Error-Correcting-Code memory, a type of memory that includes special circuitry for testing and accuracy of data as it passes in and out of memory." Most home computers use standard memory, while ECC memory is used for commercial applications where data integrity is very critical. When buying memory, the only time you will see ECC mentioned is if the memory *is* ECC, not if it is *not* ECC. ECC memory is also more expensive since it has an extra memory chip and circuitry to do the error correction. Basically, the CL tells you how many clock cycles it takes to perform an action, so the less the better.

Question: My computer runs windows 8.1 - do you think that has changed with a newer version?
Answer: The OP (operating program) and the RAM (Random Access Memory) are not the same. RAM is where the program or any other 'working program' on your computer resides. When your computer 'BOOTS Up', it is taking a computer program from the hard drive and loading it onto the RAM. 'Windows 8.1' is the operating program that is loaded into (or onto) RAM and directs what takes place and how information that you type in under a 'prompt' or from an internal command derived from the program. TWO completely different things!

Question: Is this card an upgrade to an NVIDEA GT610 1 GB DDR3?
Answer: The short answer is, yes but mostly for the additional VRAM. The chip itself isn't much better. Within a series, it's easy to tell what you are getting based on price. NVIDIA 6 series cards (610,620,...650,660,670) get better as you go up in number. And the price goes up as well. It's harder to compare outside of a series. For example an old 260 will outperform a 620. The second number represents the power, and the first number represents the generation. So the 260 is four generations older but it's way higher in the power number. This is a pretty basic answer, but hope it helps.

Question: I ordered the UB1280 battery from RU (MH20567). I received the Vision SCP1280F2--are they the same?
Answer: The key info with respect to the battery capacity here is the 1280 (which translates to 12V 8.0 AH). Whether or not the batteries are equivalent (and will work in your application) will come down to the physical dimensions and location of the positive/negative terminals. Sometimes the batteries may be electrically equivalent, but you need to be careful about the dimensions of the case. Be extra careful of the location of the terminals to make sure that the positive/negative are on the proper sides for your use.

Question: I don't need a replacement battery at this time. If I buy this battery now and keep it in storage, how many years would the battery still be usable when I need to use it when my old battery dies?
Answer: Less than a year. Sealed lead acid batteries need to be kept on charge or else they undergo something called sulfation, which is terminal to the battery. Buying one ahead of time and storing it is a bad idea.

Question: Do you really think that i need to buy a kit of 2 of these memory? I have a Macbook pro 2012 with 4 GB of RAM,
Answer: It is not necessary to install DDR3 memory sticks in pairs, however you will experience much better performance if you do because DDR3 memory is optimized to operate twice as fast in dual channel mode in matched pairs, as is your current configuration. Although the 2012 MacBook Pro has an "official" 8GB limit it can actually address 16GB. You will get much faster performance by upgrading to 8GB using two matched 4GB sticks rather than installing just one 8GB stick with the existing 2GB stick. Why upgrade memory capacity but downgrade performance by installing only one stick?

Question: I am trying to find a camera that takes extremely clear pictures...I have had other Sonys, Canons, Nikons etc. and none are as clear as I would like. I have a Pentax 645N and it takes the clearest pictures of any camera I have ever had. To people who...
Answer: The Sony RX100 is the best compact around for the time being (and you can now go for the RX100 II for which they added some nice and useful goodies) if not considering kind of compact cameras with fixed lenses with a fixed focal distance (no zoom) as the Nikon Coolpix A. But if the image quality of the RX100 is not enough for you, forget about compact cameras and try with a semi-compact with a bigger sensor, for example, something as the Sony NEX 7. If that does not still fulfill your expectations, you can always go for a full-frame or you could spend about 7.000 U$S and update to the Pentax 645D (which is a medium format camera). You can always check and compare camera sensor ratings done (benchmarked) by DxOMarks for different cameras, at this site http://www.dxomark.com/index.php/Cameras/Camera-Sensor-Ratings

Question: Is this a way so you can send the computer's active image to a tv over hdmi? Somewhat like chromecast by google?
Answer: This could be used to send a computers active image to a more remote TV (or monitor) provided: 1. the source computer has an HDMI output (or output that can be converted to HDMI); 2. there is an available (i.e. unused for any other purpose) single CAT5 cable that runs from the source computer to the remote TV; and 3. the remote TV has an HDMI input (or input that can be converted to HDMI).

Question: would this work in dell optiplex 745 minitower even though my motherboard says its pci express 1.0 and this card says PCI Express 2.0?

With the price point on this the way it is, you reduction in performance is probably not a big deal. I would caution against using modern video cards with older power supplies. Generally, for modern graphics cards a 500W p/s is a minimum starting point--I would not go under 400W.

Question: Does this work for Minecraft on PC? What about games on Steam?
Answer: Minecraft doesn't have native controller support, as of 1.6.2 at least. In my experience, Super Street Fighter IV AE, most emulators, and Cave Story+ can work natively as long as you plug it in before starting the game; just make sure to bind all of your controls to buttons. For games that use Xinput (used by games for native Xbox 360 controller support), use 360ce to fool them into thinking your Wii controller is a 360 pad; just be aware that it involves .dll files, which VAC doesn't like when they're played with when it comes to some games. For games that don't have any kind of good controller support, your next best bet is a program that translates controller input into keybindings and/or mouse movement. Xpadder is one such program.

Question: What is the second Gbn connection for? The documentation on the ubiquiti site only says that the second Gbn is for bridging. Any details?
Answer: The secondary port simply acts like an additional switchport to which you can connect a (non-POE) device, such as an IP camera. It is a bridged port and is non-configurable. It cannot be used for link aggregation.

Question: Can someone explain why we need to set a generic master SSID for this AP? Normally we determine an SSID for each radio band and guests... Tks!

Question: What comes in the box with this Ubiquti. Do i need my own network cables etc?
Answer: As I recall, just the mounting hardware. This is an enterprise product so it would generally mounted high on a wall or ceiling (which is why it has the design shape it does), It is (quite reasonably, IMHO) assumed that it is going to be a permanent, wired-in solution and in that case you would most likely be running a long Cat5/6 cable to it from your router thru the walls and/or ceiling. If you do not have the ability to do this, a simpler shelf mounted unit might be better for your use. Worth the effort if you can install it as getting access points up high results in better coverage in most places. It also looks cool, like a large smoke detector with a glowing blue ring.

Question: Can it control an attached AM21 and record OTA programs from it?
Answer: My neighbor and I both have the same unit, the THR22. The AM21 works great, just not with the THR22. The THR22 still records from local via sat. Also, if you cancel service, like neighbor did, the THR22 unit becomes doorstop and usb stops working also. Directv would not add it to my account even though neighbor paid for unit outright. I haven't tried it since last year, but in any event Tivo has a much better than average cust knowledge base, unlike DIRECTV worth calling. I still have DIRECTV and like it, so I'm not slamming them perse. IN any event, my conversations with both companies informally leads me to believe that Directv really does not care to much for Tivo and the two units are not supported together. I have no doubt that some hack somewhere might have cracked them to work together, but it would probably violate several state and federal laws in the process. Call Tivo and ask them.

Question: Right now I have the DTV multi room genie set up with HR24 for head unit, will this new TiVo work with existing wiring? Thanks

If you just plug it in where a c41-700 network box is it will not work. If you are replacing the Genie, then it will work. Network availability, just like the Genie is also required for proper functioning. Hope it helps.

Question: These headphones seem to have a noticeable electronic whine when not playing music but with active NC on...is this normal?

Should it be noticable with music, no. This is common with all active noise reducing headphones. However, I would not describe this as a whine. But a very low toned air flowing hum almost like wind blowing through a very light hum.

Question: Can you disable the fan or quiet it down in some other way?

The fan is quiet enough that you should not be bothered by it, if you are listening to music, watching tv or movies (even if you are listening to them at low volumes).

Question: If using in RAID 1 and one HDD fails, do I just plug a new HDD and the enclosure will mirror the good HDD to it?
Answer: That really is about all there is to it. Of course, during the process your new drive will be appropriately partitioned, formatted, etc...but it is all handled by your RAID software. Just be aware that when you buy a replacement drive, if you buy one that is larger or has a faster rotational speed than your remaining drive, the performance of the replacement drive will be limited to matching the size and speed specifications of the remaining drive. (Don't buy a 4 TB drive if the remaining drive is 1 TB...it will work, but you will lose 3 TB of usable space.)

Question: I was given a pair of WD 600 GB Velociraptor drives. Would this enclosure accommodate their heat sinks/size and keep them cool enough?
Answer: Heat output of HD's varies widely, but the design of the aluminum case and the fan in the rear give as good a cooling as you are going to get in a Mirrored external case.

Question: Has anyone used this product with a mac? If so what is your experience? I plan to find a USB enclosure to connect two 750GB drives in RAID 0.
Answer: I used this on my Mac and it corrupted two of my drives. I sent it back for an exchange due to a problem with the power supply. Vantec was less than helpful with the corrupted drives. My hard drives worked when I pulled them out of the computer but after using their faulty enclosure it was corrupted, somehow they claim there's no way to tell their enclosure caused the damage. I would never put my hard drives into another Vantec enclosure.

Question: Are you able to format the drives as you want like FAT 32 or NTFS?
Answer: This is not a NAS it is hardware RAID it's just like a RAID controller in a server you can partition and format the RAID volume in any way supported by the OS. I've even used these with Mac OS X and Linux and had no problems with MBR or GPT partition tables, complicated partition schemes, HFS+, LVM, BTRFS, XFS etc. With Windows 7 or newer it registers as an internal disk instead of a removable drive so NTFS works but you will have to jump through some hoops to get FAT32 just like you would with a regular disk ExFAT may be easier. FAT32 has some applications but is insecure that's why MS made it difficult to access in newer OS.

Question: If using Raid 1, how should I do to switch a fail HDD? Do I have to switch it while power is on?
Answer: No. It should be powered off.

Question: Does this come with any software to manage the RAID? What file system does the RAID use?
Answer: No, it's a hardware RAID enclosure. The RAID mode is set via a pair of jumpers inside the unit and any file system is supported. The unit appears as a single disk to the OS once configured.

Question: Will this work with solid state drive
Answer: I'm very sure it will work with SSDs but you probably won't get the performance you expect. It would be more economical to get much cheaper HDDs.

Question: Any tips on cleaning the keyboard? I've had it for over a year and am having major issues with sticking keys. I clean it once a week with canned air
Answer: I use a compressor because of the extra pressure but if you don't have one the compressed air in a can that you are already using is the only option. Words of caution, just don't shake it first and make sure to keep it upright otherwise the liquid will come out into your keyboard. If you only spray the air while it is sitting flat you may not be getting everything out of the keyboard. I like to turn mine upside down and rotate on all sides to make sure everything has a chance to come out. If any liquids (soda, coffee, libations, etc) have been spilled into the keyboard then the compressed air or air compressor may not work for you, you may need to replace the keyboard. There are plenty of places online to purchase a replacement keyboard and instructions to get it done. They can usually be found for under 25 bucks. Takes about 45 minutes or less and just about anyone can do it with the online instructions. Hope this helps Dave

Question: How does Windows 7 do with legacy software? I have some software from 2000 that I'm still using (Quickbooks, Quicken), and don't wish to upgrade.
Answer: Well, there are several ways you can have Windows 7 running legacy software. Windows has functions like compatibility settings and other options to try to emulated the old environments, but perhaps the most suitable tool to certify you can run your legacy software is Windows XP Mode (http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/windows7/install-and-use-windows-xp-mode-in-windows-7), you don't need a valid license as its include within the solution and it comes from Microsoft, so you don't have to worry about spyware or other third party software affecting your computer. This solution is transparent to the user, so you will have a single icon of your legacy software (Quickbooks, Quicken, etc) on your Windows 7 Desktop. The requirements for this solution are specified on the link provided. I use this on my work every day, so I can assure you it works. About the performance, I can tell you that if you have at least 2 o 4 GB of ram you will be more than ready to use it. Good Luck.

Question: This unit will not play from folders on a usb stick and my computor will only download into folders on the sticks. How are folders eliminated???
Answer: I was successful with playing music from the GOgroove. I had a folder called music on my USB and I put one song in the folder. Once you plug the USB into the GOgroove it will find and play the song. I then tried multiple songs and they played sequentially. All computers will download to the root folders of any drive and it may be easier to put the songs on the USB in the root folders. The GOgroove does play songs from the USB and will find them and play them sequentially from all folders on the USB. The con is that you cannot select the order of play.

Question: How is it wired? It seems to have 8 pins. Keys are binary encoded over the wires? Short circuited when pressed? What if multiple keys are pressed?
Answer: There are 8 pins. If this were binary encoded, we'd only need 5. Instead, this uses a matrix. There's a pin for each row, and a pin for each column. To read a key press, we check for current between a particular row, and a particular column. This works fine for one key press, but it's not good for more than one. EG: 1 and 5 being pressed looks the same to the computer as 1, 2, 4, and 5 being pressed simultaneously, because both scenarios result in current in the same pair of columns and rows. Also, google keypad wiring for some great examples of how to use this.

Question: how does this item work ?
Answer: Thread the lock around some heavy or immovable object, then insert the "T-bar" on the end of the combination cylinder and change the number. This locks the T-bar into the laptop until you turn the combination lock to the correct number. Question: how do I install?
Answer: The tip of the lock is T-shaped. This part goes into an ovoid shaped hole in your equipment. When you unlock the combination, you will be able to twist the T-shaped tip 90 degrees which secures it inside the hole. If you can't find the hole, find the documentation for your device and look for something called Kensington Lock in the diagram. Laptops, PCs and extrernal hard drives usually have a Kenington lock port somewhere on them.

Question: Does this fit a 13" MacBook Pro?
Answer: Pretty much every electronic device has a Kensington slot. And yes, this will fit into the little "slot" next to the Superdrive of a 13" MacBook Pro. All apple computers have a Kensington lock slot.

Question: I've got this Uniden system to send email messages, how do I get it to send SMS or MMS message notifications?
Answer: wireless carriers have an email address that correlates to your phone numbers...i.e. for VZW, it's xxxYYYZZZZ@vtext.com, where the xxx is your area code and YYY and ZZZ are the rest of your phone number. So, the Uniden is really just sending an email to another email address that converts it to a SMS or MMS text that your phone can receive. This article can help explain it, although some of the email addresses are probably a bit dated (check with your carrier for the most current format): http://computer.howstuffworks.com/e-mail-messaging/how-to-send-text-messages-computer.htm

Question: I'm not sure I understand the benefit / speed difference between an AC router (or even N) and a "wired" Ethernet connection??
Answer: Wired connections are rated in as a number. There's 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, and 1000 Mbps (also called Gigabit, as 1000 Mbps = 1 Gbps). Depending on your network hardware and how much you want to spend, you can go faster, but those are the typical residential wired network speeds available. Similarly, wireless connections are also rated as a number. Wireless B (802.11b, circa 1999) is rated for 11 Mbps, wireless G (802.11g, circa 2002) is 54 Mbps. Wireless N (802.11n, circa 2007) is really the first wireless that can truly simulate a wired connection in terms of speed. Wireless N routers are sold with ratings in increments of 150 Mbps. This is why you see Wireless N150, N300, N450, N600, etc devices when you shop for one. N150 is 150 Mbps, N300 is 300 Mbps, and so on. Devices achieve these rates with by using multiple antennas and other multiplexing structures. The Asus AC-66U, when running in wireless N mode, (if I remember correctly, I can't find the spec on their website) is an N450 device. Thus, it runs at 450 Mbps. If your wired link is only 100 Mbps, this would offer a significant speed increase for the link between the router and client device. Wireless AC is the next revision of the wireless protocol (802.11ac). As you can tell from the title ("AC1750"), when running in wireless AC mode, this runs at 1750 Mbps, or 1.75 Gbps, almost twice as fast as a wired gigabit link. Wireless AC is still relatively new, and as such only very new devices have it (the Samsung Galaxy S4 and HTC One, for example, support 802.11ac), but you can be assured that almost every device that comes on the market beginning in 3-6 months on will support it and it will become just as ubiquitous as 802.11g and 802.11n have been. The main benefits to wired connections are the lack of interference, simple network security protocols (i.e. you require physical access to the network to access it), and a consistent speed link and latency. Wireless speeds and signal can fluctuate depending on other electronics in your home, the makeup of your home's building materials, and your location within/around it. However, even given these caveats, generally speaking, wireless is more than good enough for most folks to ditch a home wired network, saving the cost of implementing one if it doesn't already exist, so long as they don't leave their network open and use WPA2 to secure it with an effective passphrase. Wireless networks offer the speeds of wired networks, but with the added ability of being a mobile user, and the huge convenience of a quick and easy setup for locations without a pre-existing wired network. That being said, unless you're a Google Fiber subscriber or somewhere else with a 1 Gbps connection, the largest -- by far -- traffic bottleneck is your internet connection (cable/DSL/FIOS). While the increase in speeds with a new router might speed up response times and transfers between devices on your local network, the jump between N and AC will largely go unnoticed if the majority of your traffic goes to the internet. Still, with the constant march forward of technology in all aspects, I think it a worthwhile investment to spend a little more to purchase a quality AC router, of which this device certainly qualifies, rather than a wireless N router. If you already have a wired network, and mobile device speeds are not a concern, then you could just use a less expensive wireless router with gigabit ports to connect your wired links to. This could even be a wireless N device, if wireless speed was of no concern to you, and won't be in the future. If you're in that boat, then it would probably be worthwhile to investigate a lower cost option that would meet your need instead, as this router tends to be at the top of the price range because of it's 802.11ac support and large feature set. If a simple wired network is all you need, then it could be seen by some as overkill. Hope that answers your question. EDIT: Added a bit more about if you have an existing wired network.

Question: When in Access Point mode, are the guest networks firewalled off from your private network?

I ended up hanging an old AP off the DMZ of my firewall port for guest access and use the AC66U as my main AP for the wireless devices in the home. Other than that, the device seems decent enough. Question: does this support dd-wrt?
Answer: Yes. This is supported by dd-wrt. You can type in "asus" here and see that this model is fully supported. http://www.dd-wrt.com/site/support/router-database Also, security is the best reason to use dd-wrt on any router you can. If you've listened to the tech news lately you know that home routers firmware tend to be full of bugs that aren't always fixed and home routers are becoming a major attack vector. It isn't worth it for most manufacturers to continue to update their older routers firmware b/c they want you to purchase new one. So yes, it is supported and, yes it is important. :)

Question: Does it have built in Parental controls?
Answer: Yes, the router has built-in parental controls that allow you to restrict specific devices for specific times as well as block specific URLs. In addition, you can set time limits on each guest network (there are 6 total, 3 2.4ghz and 3 5ghz). The biggest problem with the parental controls is the URL filtering is "dumb" in that you have to enter each restricted URL and there is a limit of 128. You'll find that you can easily find more than 128 anonymous proxy servers on the internet and if you can find them, so can your teens. You cannot whitelist and while you can keyword filter, it's a chainsaw approach.

Question: Does anybody have experience on how it stands up to rain or humid environments? I live in the NW where it rains often, but would like to use it on a keychain that hangs from my pants loop. Thanks!

With normal non-high-acid rain the only important thing is to never plug it in until it is completely dry inside. Since it is fairly difficult to be sure a semi-sealed case USB drive is completely dry inside the easy answer is don't get it wet. There's really no reason to have it hanging from a heychain on a pants loop outside. The extra bulk will just cause it to bang against things a lot while there are other drives with no possible way for water to get in.

Question: Is there a similarly fast (but doesn't need to be *identically* so) 64GB USB 3.0 drive, but much smaller? Broke my Sandisk because stuck out too much.

With today's existing tech in the marketplace, nothing small is even half as fast although some products out there only mention misleading best case scenario read speeds while this Sandisk Extreme has the distinction of having the highest performance across several other parameters more relevant to real world use. A safer way to use it would be to put it on a short USB3 extension cord.

Question: If I uninstall any software SanDisk installs on my PC, and reformat the flash drive, does that permanently remove SanDisk software from the drive?
Answer: No, but it will keep the software from working or taking up space. Simple deletion will remove data/files for your use, but not prevent someone from reading it if they get access to the drive. Based on your question I assume you are using are using a PC, not a MAC. As someone who has worked in computer security, I can tell you that reformatting a drive does not remove the information. It simply removes the map of where the information can be found. The information is still on the drive and could be found and accessed by someone with the requisite equipment. That is because when you "delete" information from a drive or reformat it, it only removes the map of where the information is located. You would need to overwrite the files with other data to assure it is not accessed by someone. Experts recommend random overwriting it at least 7 times. There are a number of programs that will do this. If you need a free data eraser, I suggest you consider using Eraser Software. See: http://oithelp.nd.edu/information-security/faq/securely-erasing-usb-devices/ You should be able to download this software at: http://sourceforge.net/projects/eraser/files The above applies to both hard drives and USB Thumb Drives/Flash Drives. If you are not worried about someone accessing the information on your drive, just delete it and you are good to go. I hope this helps.

Question: my pc indicates only 29gb total storage on the 32gb flashdrive??
Answer: Manufactures report the number of bits usable by their drives assuming that a kilobyte is 1000 bits (decimal thinking), while Windows reports the number of bits assuming a kilobyte is 1024 bits (binary thinking). Google "(1000^3 * 32 * 8) / (1024^3 * 8)" to get the amount of space in GiB, which is how much usable space you have as reported in the Windows operating system. Windows should report 29.8 GB usable on a freshly formatted drive. This has *nothing* to do with Windows 8 certification.

Question: I just need USB to both 5VDC and 3.3VDC to power an airport express. Im confused by terms TTL, TX, RX will this cable work just as a power supply?
Answer: Hi Zachary ... Appears this is not what you want. [I am unclear if an Airport Express can be powered via USB and not its own power adapter.] This specifically is a USB-to-serial data cable with a built in UART chip. There can be very low levels of 3.3v or 5v generated (varies with various models) but that's not gonna drive a whole big device like Airport - more to drive one or two chips on a small board. This is designed for making your USB-equipped PC - desktop or laptop - look like it has a built-in COMn: serial port. FYI, "TTL" means transitor-to-transistor logic levels (meaning 5VDC), and Tx & Rx are the UART lines for transmitted & received serial data at logic level (not +/- 10+ VDC swing used by actual RS232 line levels).

Question: Why does the description say "RS232"? This seems to be for TTL, which is 3.3v and not compatible with RS232.
Answer: This is correct - RS232C does not use TTL levels and so strictly speaking this adapter isn't "RS232". However it does provide the same set of signaling wires and the same logical protocol as RS232C.

Question: How does this model, SE-218, differ from the similar Samsung model SE-208?
Answer: You can google Samsung SE-208 and SE218 to get comparative information. Because I was curious, I looked into it for you and called Samsung directly to ask what is the difference between the SE-208AB, -208DB and -218BB in a nutshell because all the specifications and prices I found were so similar, and there were contradictions between the Amazon and the Samsung specs. Having the actual SE-218BB item on hand, I can say that the dimensions, weight and USB port given in the Amazon description are wrong and the actual specs are more in line with those given on the "official" specs from the Toshiba/Samsung website, so the other specs on that website may also be more reliable: http://www.tsstodd.com/WebManual/External/SE-208AB/en/Specifications.html http://www.tsstodd.com/WebManual/External/SE-208DB/en/Specifications.html http://www.tsstodd.com/WebManual/External/SE-218BB/en/Specifications.html Comparisons indicate that all 3 are virtually identical in performance description and design, with minor differences in weight and slimness. The 208DB and 218BB appear to be the later versions in that they can accommodate USB 3.0 as well as 2.0 (also judging by the prices and "first available" date on Amazon). The Samsung tech, who said you can't judge by the sequence of model numbers, was of little help here as he said the only way to tell when a model was released was by the firmware number (which refers to hardware as well as software) on each item....but you have to buy the item first before you can see it, so what good is that in decision making?? At any rate, the Samsung tech agrees that you'd probably get the same performance and functionality from any of them, but the SE-208AB (0.81" tall, 10.6 oz, USB2.0, Amazon $29.99, rank #7) is likely the oldest model, and with only a $5 differential in price between the three, and the SE-218BB being only a tad slimmer and lighter (0.55" tall, 9.0 oz, USB 3.0/2.0, Amazon $35.12, rank #1) than the SE-208DB (0.81" tall, 10.6 oz, USB3.0/2.0, Amazon $30.69, rank #2) it seems just a toss-up and personal preference between the latter 2, in my opinion.

Question: Does this adapter work with the old T shaped macbook charger (the white one)?
Answer: Not sure Richard's answer was what you are looking for. Apple had two versions of the original MagSafe connector. The first was the T-shaped white one, with the electric contacts at the end of the DC cord, so the cord came straight out of the computer. The second was silver, with the electric contacts at a right angle, so the cord lies against the computer. However, these two styles of cord used exactly the same connector at the computer. Then Apple came out with MagSafe 2, which uses a narrower connector at the computer. This adapter converts a MagSafe plug on the DC cable of an Apple power supply to connect to a MagSafe 2 jack on a computer. It should work with either the original white T-shaped MagSafe DC plug, or with the newer right-angle silver MagSafe DC plug. So the simple answer should be "yes".

Question: what is the difference between magsafe and magsafe 2
Answer: MagSafe and ms2 are different size connections to MacBooks. The newer MacBooks and airs have a different magnetic connection but same power need as older ones. I bought a 2013 MacBook Air but had several power supplies from an older air. These allow me to use my power supplies I have in multiple places (travel bag, vacation place, etc.) to change from old to new. And still let's spouse use same power cord for his older macbook. Saved me from spending more on MagSafe 2 power supplies.

Question: what is the difference between a charger and an adapter

Question: Can I use the line out to connect a subwoofer amp and still use the other speaker connections from this unit?
Answer: Short answer is yes. The signal goes out of both the high and low outputs together. I tried it. It worked but I realized to get enough volume to the sub to make it sound good, you were distorting the power to the speakers. They were also really drowned out by the sub. My recommendation and what I ended up doing was to get a 4 channel amp, bridging two channels for the sub and using the other two channels for the speakers. With the amp crossovers, you can really dial in the sound and get the best bang out is the sub. Good luck.

Question: can i connect an amp for the rear channel and run the front off of the deck itself

Question: Is this product MAC compatible?
Answer: The cassette player itself is MAC compatible. The software that comes with it is not. You will need to use a free program called Audacity to use the cassette recorder with your MAC. After you import using Audacity, you can then either keep using Audacity, or you can use various MAC audio tools to edit the .mp3.

Question: I have cassettes with long family conversations I'd like to convert. Since some have said it only does one song at a time, wondering if it will work.
Answer: It will record until you press the stop button in Audacity, so you can record a whole side of a cassette in one go. However, if you want to separate individual songs from an album, so you can save them as individual digital files, you need to record one song at a time.

Question: Can this be used just as a battery operated cassette walkman type player or USB powered only?

Question: how can i get my tape to mp3 converter to work
Answer: Don't use the CassetteMare software. It doesn't work. Use the Audacity software that's also provided on the CD in the package, then follow the instructions provided with the Audacity software, not the Audacity instructions in the manual provided in the package. That manual is useless. With a little effort, you can convert tapes to mp3s using Audacity.

Question: Dear FONESO, I purchased the Handy USB Cassette Player and Tape-to-MP3 Digital Converter. Stereo playback doesn't work. What can I do?
Answer: Here are some suggestions. They may seem obvious solutions, but hopefully one of these will help you... -Check your computer's speaker volume level -Check the volume on the cassette player -Check the playback volume on the Audacity program's volume level is turned up -Make sure that the player is plugged into the microphone port and not the headphone port (if you did accidently plug it into the headphone port, then the Audacity program did not record any of it and you'll need to completely re-download the cassette recording)

Question: I need just a simple playing cassette player we are teaching our grandson hooked on phonics
Answer: This would probably work although it's not very durable, so keep that in mind. There is a headphone jack connection and also a place for batteries so you don't need to use the USB connection.

Question: Does this record 320kbps Mp3s??
Answer: Not sure. See if this makes any sense to you:The number of computer bits conveyed or processed per unit of time. Normally expressed in kilobits per second (kbps). For an uncompressed, PCM file, kbps bit rate is sample rate multiplied by sample format mutiplied by number of channels, divided by 1000, giving 1411 kbps for Red Book WAV or AIFF. Rates are much lower for compressed or lossy formats and are independent of sample rate for MP3. All I know is that you can convert into various formats. I do MP3, but you can also do MP4, WAVE, FLAC (I think)... The only way for me to check that for you is to record something and then open the Export option and it gives you a choice of format. If this info doesn't help, let me know, and I will hook it back up and record a sample and see. It is a really good gadget and easy to operate. I haven't used the splicing and editing mode, but it offers a lot of functions for editing, etc. I recommend this. The above info was taken from the Help info supplied with the program.

Question: Can I use this to transfer files from a dead laptop harddrive to a new laptop without taking the harddrive out of the new laptop?
Answer: You will need to take the hard drive out of the broken laptop. That hard drive would then plug in to the large end, then plug the two USB ends in to the new laptop. But this will only work if your old drive is a SATA drive. If it is a very old IDE drive it will not work. (IDE Drives are the old hard drives that have two rows of small pins on the). Removing a hard drive from a laptop is super easy. You will probably find videos on your specific laptop on YouTube.

Question: will this work on a sata 500gb drive?

Question: Plugged it in and my PC is recognizing the cable but not the HDD, HDD is also silent. I made sure to format the driver earlier, and it's worked before
Answer: Unplug and replug the cable into the hard drive and the computer. There are many tiny connectors, and sometimes if the plug is even a little crooked it won't work. If that doesn't work, try it with another hard drive, to see if it's the adapter, or your drive. Also, if you are trying to use only one USB plug, use the one in the middle of the cord. The plug on the end is just for extra power (in case a single USB port doesn't have enough juice to power up the drive; I've never had to use it).

Question: Does this work with 3.5 inch hard drives or only with 2.5 in?

Question: I have one signal of 5v and i need open one electric lock (door access) of 12 V? I can used it for convert my signal of 5v to 12v?
Answer: That depends on the power / current requirements of your door lock. If it is a 1A 12V lock then that means your input current would have to be 2.4A even if the buck/boost converter was 100% energy efficient and had no loss. Since there will be conversion losses your input current (for a 1A 12V load) is probably at the 3A maximum rating for this converter. If your lock requires more then 1A then this is not the correct DC-DC converter to use for your application. Also make sure that your signal source can supply 5V at the required current. If the input voltage drops because of the load then the input current will increase even further.

Question: DellUP2414Q UHD gives only2calibration slots per input so I want to hook PC to it&toggle between DP&mDP inputs so I get 4 calibrations. This works?
Answer: I didn't know the answer off the top of my head, so I looked it up on the Lenovo site, which stated, in relevant part: Lenovo DisplayPort to Dual DisplayPort Adapter (0B47092) provides multi-monitoring at its finest without the use of an expensive graphics card. The two modes supported are Expanded mode and Mosaic mode. In Expanded mode, one ThinkCentre DisplayPort can be connected to two identical monitors with one DisplayPort to Dual DisplayPort Adapter and two Options DisplayPort cables (0A36537). In Quad Mosaic mode, two ThinkCentre DisplayPorts can be connected to four identical monitors with two DisplayPort to Dual DisplayPort Adapters and four DisplayPort cables. Maximum resolution in Quad Mosaic mode supported is 3840 x 2160. I hope this answers your question.

Question: Can I charge my SOlar Monkey directly through the wall socket in Europe?
Answer: Hi Ingham, Thank you for your question for Shop Akari. There are two ways to charge your Solamonkey. You can place the unit in direct sunlight with the solar panels perpendicular to the sun. 12 hours of strong sunlight will charge the internal battery fully. or You can attach the USB / DC charging cable into any 5V USB output socket (e.g. on your computer), plugging the DC (round) end into the DC input socket located next to the 5V USB socket at the bottom of the solarmonkey adventurer. Whilst the unit is charging, the LED will show RED. Once the unit is charged, the LED will show GREEN. However, if you need the Powertraveller universal travel cord for wall charging (sold separately from the Solamonkey), we offer it at $14.40 each. This universal travel cord works in over 150 counties around the world and has 4 different interchangeable head plugs you can use depending on what continent you are in, which includes Europe. I hope this answers your question, however feel free to contact me with any other questions you may have. Thank you! Lulu Shop Akari 713-869-4656

Question: Is this solar charger the best option for backcountry travel for weeks at a time or is there anything lighter, more durable and/or more effective?
Answer: The solar charger is very durable and extremely light. It's great for short hikes not lasting more than 5 days. I have had some issues with the charger not charging an iPhone 5 with just solar power, but charging the internal battery first usually charges any phone. I only say it's good for 5 days because I haven't tried the charger for any longer of a period. It's great to clip on a pack as you travel so the internal battery gets charged and very user friendly. It is definitely great for charging phones or a small gps. Anything bigger you would have to get a charger with better output. If you are looking for an even more rugged product look at the Joos solar charger.

Question: Hooked up and getting muted sound. My old standard Sony turntable packed a much louder punch from reciver. Is this a arm weight issue? Cables?
Answer: Most likely the hook up is a balance issue . You tube has some very good how to videos that explain the balance arm . The muted sound is most likely because your receiver doesn't have a dedicated phono amp . Your old Sony turntable probably had the phono amp built in . Pro-Ject sells one for about $150.00 but you can find them for less . I had the same issue as you with the muting and was reluctant to add to the cost of an already expensive turntable but the investment is worth it .

Question: I have bumped the cartridge a few times dropping the stylus hard on the LP or on the platter, will this hurt my stylus? How do you clean it?
Answer: I have not noticed any damage from dropping the stylus, however, as I'm sure you're aware, that's probably not a good habbit to form. As far as cleaning, there are multiple products available that I'm sure would work great, but I personally use a Mr. Clean Magic Eraser. It's definitely worth doing your own research, and it's totally understandable if you want to stay away from a semi-DIY approach, but after cleaning my stylus hundreds of times I can say that I'm happy with the results. If the record itself is clean you should be able to notice an audible difference. Hope this helps.

Question: Would you use this lens for portraiture? Is it as good as the 85mm fixed lens?

Question: which lens is better for image quality on digital nikon DX camera Nikon 24-85 FX or 16- 85 DX
Answer: The 24-85 is an excellent lens that I use on my D700. However for a DX camera the 18-55mm VR is an excellent optical performer,lighter and costs less. It will also provide you with a wider angle than the 24-85. Keep in mind that the 24-85 on a DX will have the focal equivalent of 36-127mm.

Question: Will this lens work with an Nikon D2xs camera?

Question: Will this work with Nikon D5000?

Question: IS THIS LENS CAN USE IT TO TAKE MACRO PICTURES

Question: Will this lens would work better for indoor sports under not so great lighting than a 55-200 VR 4-5.6 on a D3100?
Answer: I used the 55-200mm/4-5.6 lens on my DX format D200 and thought that it was an excellent lens. There are two things that would make me prefer it to the excellent 24-85mm/3.5-5.6 in your case. First, you would probably be using the lens at longer focal lengths, in which case both lenses would be operating at f/4.5 to f/5.6, so there is no advantage to having the 24-85mm in terms of low light capability. Second, the 24-85mm is designed for the FX format, so you'd be paying for a wider field lens than you need on a DX camera. If you ever go to FX format, the 24-85mm/3.5-5.6 is a real jewel to own.

Question: is there a warranty from Nikon?
Answer: On Nikon's website it says: Nikkor lenses come with a standard one year warranty and Nikon Inc. lenses sold by authorized Nikon Inc. dealers will have a Nikon Inc. Five Year Extension. To register for the five year extension, one copy of the included form must be mailed in as indicated. Keep the Customer copy of the form as well as the original proof of purchase (sales receipt).

Question: Is this the only lens I'll ever need?
Answer: Probably so. Its range is enormous and its clarity is stunning. I've parked the two lesser lenses I used previously and am using only this lens. It is a bit heavy, but you get accustomed to it quickly. Given the great shots I've taken with this lens, it's the only lens I will use. In fact, it's the only lens I'm taking on a month long trip to Africa this year.

Question: Has anyone used this lens with a Nikon D80? How did it do?
Answer: I used this lens on my D7000 and my D80 before returning the lens because it was just a little too big and ungainly for mine or my wife's comfort, especially with respect to the smaller/lighter D80 body on which it was a bit front heavy. It performed admirably for shooting outdoor sports on each body at it's not like the lens was ridiculously big, but was quite a bit larger than our beloved 18-200 to the point of not being nearly as pleasant to work with. Tended to want the monopod to keep from getting fatigued doing extended shoots, whereas the 18-200 was fine handheld.

Question: will this work with my D-200?

Question: 18-200mm vs 18-300mm - which one would you suggest?

But if you only want one, well, a. if you value light-weight, smaller size, easier to lug around, then get the 18-200 b. if you really really want the extra zoom, and don't mind the extra mass, get the 18-300 I wanted both worlds...but I will tell you, my hand did get tired more quickly with the 18-300 mounted...and after I saw the difference in the full zoom pics, I thought to myself : "Is that all the extra I get?"....which I did want more zoom, and I am happy, but thought it would be much bigger than actual results... Holding/shooting with one hand, the 200 felt like a pleasure...the 300 felt hefty. Question: compare 18-300 vs 28-300
Answer: From what I see on Nikon's website, the 28-300 is a FX lens while the 18-300 is a DX lens. If you have a FX (full frame size sensor like D3, D600, D800) camera, you should buy the 28-300. You'd have to use the camera in crop mode if you mounted the 18-300. If you have a DX camera (D3100, D5200, D7100), you should buy the 18-300.

Question: What is the difference with this lens (AF-S DX NIKKOR 18-300mm f/3.5-5.6G ED VR) and the AF-S DX NIKKOR 18-300mm f/3.5-6.3G ED VR ?
Answer: Hi, Here is a good review from Ken Rockwell. This Nikon 18-300mm VR is a smaller, lighter version of the original 18-300mm VR. The original 18-300 was very good, so good in fact that I sold an image I made with it to McDonald's - and they are using it on a billboard. This new lens is as good, and is smaller, lighter and less expensive, so it's even better! My only real complaint about the original 18-300 was that it weighed a lot more than my camera, and this new 18-300 weighs ten ounces less! This new 18-300mm also offers Vibration Reduction (4 stops) and instant manual-focus override. It's very slightly slower at the 300mm end (f/6.3 versus f/5.6) than the older lens, and for ten ounces off my shoulder, that's nothing. By taking off 10 ounces, I now can carry this new lens everywhere I never bothered with the old 18-300. This new lens do everything, and it even does macro. At 300mm, it focuses to within just inches of the front of the lens.

Question: Would you please compare nook to kindle fire?
Answer: They both have good price points, decent interaction and speed, but both lack SD Card Slots and try to lock the system down to keep people on their respective vendor's content. Both are built on Android, but it is quite buried and not readily accessible. You would need to probably void the warranty to get to the base Android system. Here is a good side by side I found compare: http://www.gizmag.com/kindle-fire-hd-vs-nook-hd/24959/ If you already purchase music, books, movies, etc from one or the other, then I would go with that one. But if you want more freedom and long term customization, go with something that is base Android like the Lenovo S2110 or Asus Transformer Prime. Or if your on a budget, checkout the Nexus 7/10 or the Galaxy 7" If you want to get to know them in person, run down to BestBuy, Staples, Wal-mart or any store with electronics and they should have a display with each of the devices where you can get to know them. Cheers -IT Ninja

Question: Does this radio display song title and artist information? I think that's what RDS means but description doesn't say. Thx.
