Question: Powered by batteries?
Answer: There is no battery back-up. There is a large capacitor inside the unit, which will provide enough energy to get past short power glitches. The unit does not plug directly into the wall. It has a 'wall-wart', which supplies six volts unregulated, unfiltered DC to the unit. You could easily make a battery back-up, which would plug into the unit in place of the wall-wart as an extended back-up power supply. Here in Florida, the power is subject to recurring interruptions of short duration during summer thunderstorms. The unit has handled these without problems.

Question: Does the clock auto adjust for daylight saving time changes?
Answer: Yes it does but depending on where you have it, it could take a day or so. Last fall my clock changed immediately to standard time but this spring it didn't change until the next night. It was in the same spot but that also happens with other atomic clocks we have. Sometimes they change immediately, sometimes a day or two later.

Question: I'm having a hard time getting the Atomic clock to set automatically, specifically the analog clock is stuck on midnight. Any advice?
Answer: I wouldn't call it stuck. When you push the proper sequence of buttons to set the Atomic clock, it will go to midnight, and then wait to get the signal from Colorado. So, for whatever reason, it is probably not getting the signal from Colorado. It could be your local weather related or a unit malfunction. To confirm it is not really stuck, try to set the time using RBDS. That should work if you have proximity to an FM station with that service. If the clock is not stuck, I would then try the following. Unplug it for a few hours. In effect this is a reset. There is also a reset button on the bottom - it will do the same thing. Then when you are ready to start again, bring the unit to the highest point in your house facing Colorado. See if it will update. My unit is working right now, so it is not the signal from Colorado that is the problem. The clock could be malfunctining. I had another Sangean Atomic clock radio that had to be returned. But try unplugging it first.

Question: Is this lens as good as the canon 18-135 stm for doing video on the canon 70D
Answer: I have the Canon 18-135 STM and a different Sigma HSM lens. Canon's STM motor is better for video. You don't hear any focusing noise from the STM motor. Sigma's HSM motor is quiet, but makes light clicking noises as it focuses that were picked up by camera's (EOS 70D) built-in microphone. The clicking wasn't very loud. If there is a good amount of ambient noise, you probably won't notice.

Question: I bought this lens for Canon EOS 6D camera but in viewfinder I see only partial picture. Always see the lens circle around the picture. Can you help
Answer: I believe this is happening because you are using a cropped lens (the Sigma 18-250mm) on a full frame camera (the Canon EOS 6D). Although there are people who do use cropped lenses on full frame cameras (they crop the image using software after it has been taken), you would likely better be served by using a full frame lens on the camera. You can do this by checking which Canon (or aftermarket) lenses are designed for full frame use. Full frame lenses are usually heavier and more expensive, but they are designed for the larger sensor size format of full frame, and often produce more detailed images than their "cropped" sensor relatives.

Question: does this work for nikon G lens as well?

Question: Will this work with my dad's old AI lenses?
Answer: Yes. There are two versions as I understand it. The second, which I did not purchase, handles later lenses that do not have an aperture ring - I think it has its own aperture settings while the lens remains wide open. I kept several Dx lenses and DSLRs but have not tried the Dx lenses with this adapter. I think the only way they can be used is wide open, which is rather pointless. I am mounting on a Fuji X-Pro1 with a Micro-Nikkor 55mm f/2.8 (circa late 1970s) - works fine, of course manual focus only.

Question: Hi, i was about to buy this product for a fujifilm X-T1 but then i wondered if it works, and how it performs with DX Nikkor lenses. anyone? thanks
Answer: Most DX lenses are "G" designated and missing the aperture ring. This adapter does not carry any data from the lens to the camera. It also has no mechanical connection. Therefore, most DX lenses will be stuck at the smallest aperture and photos would be severely underexposed. With this adapter, you must focus and set your exposure manually. If your lens has an aperture ring and focus ring, this well-built adapter works fabulously. With focus peaking, manually focusing is a pretty quick and easy task. Keep in mind, the exif data will be missing info like aperture setting.

Question: Are you guys able to adjusts the aperture on the Nikon lenses?
Answer: I got my adapter so that I could use my older Nikon lenses with my Fujifilm X mount camera. The adapter will work with any manual focus Nikon lens (such as AI or AIS) or their D type autofocus lenses. The S type and newer lenses have no aperture rings and will not work properly with the adapter.

Question: Does this converter create a focal length conversion beyond the magnification caused by fuji's smaller sensor size? Light loss?
Answer: 1. re focal length conversion--no. 2. re light loss--I have not noted any--but, frankly, I am usually using any / all of my adapter with a fixed f-stop setting or with AE.

Question: will this work on the XE1 as well.. I would think it should but would like to confirm .... Thanks
Answer: Yes, I'm using it on an XE1. Of course you get no autofocus, and you have to enable a menu in the setup that allows the camera to take a picture without a lens. You should manually specify the focal length as well. There's an article about it: http://www.fujirumors.com/adapting-third-party-lenses/

Question: Does this work for Nikon DX lenses and does it still meter well when manually changing the aperture?
Answer: This adaptor works with Nikon lenses that have a manual aperture ring, providing for manual metering in the Fuji camera body. It will mount a DX lens but without aperture control. There is another Fotodiox adaptor that is specifically for Nikon G and DX lenses.

Question: Does this work with Fuji XE2? I am mounting Nikon AIS lens to Fuji Xe2. Thank you!

Question: I noticed the Fotodiox does not have an aperture ring. How does one adjust aperture when using this adapter?

Question: Does a 25 year old Minolta Maxxum lens adapt to a new Fujifilm X-E2..?

I believe the mount should be the same for the Maxxum series lens. Additional point about this adapter: There are no click stops for aperture. So you're pretty much on your own for deciding what exact aperture you're on between "Lock" & "Open". I guess you can do your own calibration & make markings on the adapter, but the absence of click stops means that you'd have to look at the adapter to make an aperture change. Big bummer...

Question: I need to mount a Minolta maxxum AF zoom 75-300mm to my Canon t2i. Will this adapter fit? If not, what?
Answer: Yes but I highly DO NOT recommend it. As I said before about the optical piece in it, magnifies it by 1.4x and with other lens beyond about f1.8 or so will stay around there because the optically piece is only so big. Secondly with any AF lens you want that function to work but this adapter does not connect the electrical components. I recommend if you want to use a zoom lens with AF then buy a Canon one I bought the 55-250 works greats cost between 125-175avg used if you dont mind for cheaper it will save you in the long run. Because for me after spending so much with my Minoltas I finally got a Canon for my Canon and looking back I should've avoided the adapter. Hope that helps.

Question: I have two tamron lenses (tele macro 70-210mm and AF 35-80) with a Minolta AF mount. Does this adaptor fits my lenses to a Canon EOS camera? Thanks!

Question: I saw a post that it worked with Kubuntu. Using for XBMC that has Lubuntu 12.04. What drivers if any will be needed?
Answer: The disk that came with mine had only Windows drivers. The pertinent question is what is the chipset used in this Bluetooth device, because Linux drivers will be written to the chipset, not to the brand name on the outside of the device. The device looks like a Broadcom BMC20702 device to Windows, so I would look for drivers for that device. That does not directly answer the question but it is the best I can do.

Question: How is the motor speed consistenc ad longevility? How is the sound quality? How long does it take before it breaks or the sound quality gets affected

Question: Does Hulu work? is there a hulu app?
Answer: It definitely does not. There is no Hulu or Hulu Plus app in the Google Play store, nor can you access Hulu from the browser. The two companies have yet to reach a content agreement... The negotiations have stretched on for years at this point. This is a well-known and much-discussed drawback to Google TV. As with most consumer electronics, there are workarounds, however. It is possible to enable your Google TV device to play Hulu, but they involve hacking or "rooting" the box... Ever heard of "jail-breaking" an iPhone? Same concept. Essentially you are altering the base software of the device to get around certain built-in limitations. Doing this voids the warranty and can make downloading updates difficult. It's not an option I'd suggest unless you're a very tech-savvy person with an understanding of Linux.

Question: I want to broadcast music and recorded dialogue that can be heard on fm radios within a block. Need simple plug & play sett up. Will this do it?
Answer: There are a lot of stipulations to an answer but yes, it could conceivably cover a block. The size of the block, the type of setting (urban or suburban), and other singles in the area will determine the range. The listening device will also play a role in distance as well. Just keep in mind that, if you're in the US, the FCC regulates what you can be transmitting and how far. The fines for breaking regulations are hefty and can carry jail time. That says nothing about potential civil lawsuits based on what you're broadcasting. I'm not trying to scare you. I'm just trying to point out that you should do your homework. Triangulating a signal is very easy with the right equipment and you may be attracting more attention than you originally intended.

Question: What do you think the range would be with outside antenna?

Question: How's the sound quality?
Answer: Well, Nick, contrary to what the other reviews indicate, the sound quality CAN be very good - IF it is set up properly. I also had a Ham license, I'm an electrical design engineer, a music buff, and have been involved with audio, video and RF design for several decades. I can see where there would be "issues" with sound quality if there are any shortcomings in the connections, cables, layout, impedance matching, antenna setup, audio source accuracy, etc. etc. This is not a toy, but it can act like one because it's basically sold as a "plug-and-play" device. If you use the supplied whip antenna and plug in an iPod for a music source (like many people would probably do), it will be horrible. You will get RF feedback which will add distortion, hum and all kinds of other nasty stuff to the final signal. On the other hand, if you understand and follow proper RF layout procedures, and keep the RF away from the audio and power inputs, use a proper 50-ohm antenna with a matching feedline, your results will be indistinguishable from the next radio station on the dial. Unlike previous reviewers, I HAVE tested this with professional equipment, and the test results are well worth the price of the unit. I listen to my little "station" through a very sophisticated and expensive audio system and it sounds great - and I'm very fussy about sound quality. Bottom line: It's only as good as the quality of the installation.

Question: What cain of antenna do i need to transmit in SW(shortwave)?
Answer: Your question makes no sense for this item, and I don't know what you mean by "cain"... Is it "kind"? Is it "gain? First of all, this is an FM broadcast band transmitter - it's not even close to shortwave. Shortwave radio covers an entirely different range of frequencies, and is mostly AM (not FM). The antenna depends more on the frequency, not the transmitter. Secondly, if you don't know these basics, you should not be buying anything like this.

Question: Since this xmitter has the FCC Part 15 Certification stamped on it, why would it be illegal as other comments have suggested?
Answer: If you go to the FCC site (FCC Application number 686762), the type approval number, 2ABT5AX05B7C, on 23 January 2015, was withdrawn by Delia W. See https://apps.fcc.gov/oetcf/eas/reports/ViewExhibitReport.cfm?mode=Exhibits&RequestTimeout=500&calledFromFrame=N&application_id=686762&fcc_id=2ABT5AX05B7C The interior pictures with the filing appear to have been from an earlier version. i.e. The label is for a different model that is similar in appearance. Finding the type approval application is difficult as the withdrawal makes searching on the type approval number impossible. Use the application number instead. Too bad, it was a really nice product.

Question: is this fully assembled ready to use
Answer: Mostly! You need to wire up the two legs of the included power supply transformer - the two blue wires go to the 120v terminals of the device, and the two white wires go to the 6.3volt terminals of the device. You also need to wire a power cord to the other end of the trafo, the two red wires combine to the positive terminal wire (2 reds to white) and the two blacks to negative terminal (2 blacks to black) That's about it. It's also a good idea to either set up a proper enclosure, or at least mount the standoffs to a small board. Also, I highly recommend upgrading the stock no name Chinese tubes to GE Jan 5670w tubes - the stock tubes sound okay, but the little pre gets very pretty sounding with a good set of vintage tubes. You should be able to score a pair for around ten or fifteen bucks shipped via fleabay or the like. Note - this is a preamp - it doesn't make things super loud, and it won't drive anything by itself, but if you want to be able to put this between a source you want to get warm spacious tone from, say a turntable or ipod, and your regular stereo or power amp, this is a steal! Link is to photos of mine for context. https://www.dropbox.com/sc/ty97l22jf4rsrqf/AADETFc_i4qONVVuUan-L9EYa

Question: My transformer only has one pair of blue wires, one pair of white and one pair of red. There are no black wires. Any tips on how to wire this for 110V
Answer: Red is the 120v AC side(input) The white wires is 6.3v AC (heaters) and the blue wires are 170v AC for the tubes.. White wires go into the 6.3v terminals, and the blue wires go into the 170v terminals.

Question: I only want to register distance hiked. Can you give me simple instructions to do that?
Answer: Well if you are like me you keep experimenting until you figure out what works. There are lots of options, lots of screens, so it can be confusing. But the GPS workout screen is the second screen of the four main screens. Use the mode button to get to the second screen. On the second screen press and hold the Lap/Reset button to activate the GPS then before you take another step press the Start/Stop button. Start hiking now. When you finish press the Start/Stop button and hold down the Lap/Reset button to turn off the GPS. Don't get in the car and drive away without turning your GPS off or your are going to mess up your data when you download the data from you watch. You can see your distance as you hike and you can also see it on the map when you download your data to the runtastic website. That's what works for me, hope it helps.

Orient it so that the strap runs top to bottom of your phone, not across it. Some people like to place it an angle, though that may not make it as comfortable to use from both sides. How long does it take to ship? - Once you've placed an order on our site it will be in the mail within 24 hours! If for some reason you do not receive your SlingGRIP as quickly as you had expected, please don't hesitate to get in touch with us at - beth@slinggrip.com. How do I remove it if I need to? - You can remove a SlingGRIP by pulling very slowly from one end of the strap. Do not pull too fast you risk pulling the back off your phone or damaging the grip. Question: Okay, I just got the thing and it doesn't work. I plug it into my Sony HDR-SR11 microphone spot and it completely turns off the sound. What do I do
Answer: Okay, first thing you must and I cant stress this enough but you must know how your camera mic jack is wired. All of my cameras that I use are canon and pentax. They are all stereo mic inputs. That means it uses 3 connectors. If you dont know what I am talking about... Take a look at a plug on a pair of headphones vs the plug that is on the mic. Chances are your camera is wire like this or real similar. I do not use the cable that comes with the mic. I use one made by Hosa that has XLR on the mic end and it has a 3 connectore(stereo)plug on the camera end. The mic is not stereo, it just simply sends the same mic signal to the tip and the ring on the stereo plug. The cable in known as a dual mono cable. If you do not use this cable the adapter that you get with the mic will ground the mic line and quite possibly do what you are experiencing. I use this mic in many situations and it works great. I get great results everytime but again it is very important that you use the right connector cable.

Question: I see in the Product Description it says: "Push switch to 'TELE' for short distance or to 'NORMAL' for long distance" Is it not the other way around?

Question: How can I use this with my old Bose 5 speaker system with all the speakers connected to the Sub Woofer??
Answer: Yes, you can. Think of this system as an invisible wire to your speakers. You hook the speakers themselves to the receiving units with speaker wire, just like they were at the back of your sub. Then at the sub, you hook the wires from the transmitter in the old spot where you pulled out the original wires that went to your back speakers, and it should work like a charm.

Question: Has anyone had any issues with interference with any other 5.8GHz signals in their home. I noticed my landline cordless phone is on this frequency.
Answer: I would not recommend this kit if you are using certain types of 5.8 GHz cordless phones such as the Panasonic Gigarange series as these phones send out a tremendous amount of interference on all channels. However, the product should work fine with 5.8 GHz video transmitters which are fixed frequency and obviously wireless networks. If you do experience wireless interference with a wireless network then you can simply set the router to avoid specific channels. My friend was able to resolve a problem with his Apple Airport Extreme by manually setting the channel. Most new phones are using the DECT standard and thus won't interfer with this kit at all.

Question: Hey, whats the maximum accelaration this can handle. I have an application that will achieve over 100g's so.....
Answer: If you haven't already, look up the datasheet for the chip on the board. If you're wondering about its connections to the board & the rest of the components, I have genuinely no idea. That's an interesting materials science question involving how the board was soldered, etc. Generally speaking, though, I imagine the manufacturer would tell you if the board (here the MPU-6050) is expected to handle more acceleration than the board on which it's mounted. These units are cheap enough that you can just test one, and intuitively 100G doesn't seem too bad, so you're probably OK as long as the spec sheet says the MPU-6050 will survive it.

Answer: Read the product page.

Question: Sorry, should have been more clear. Can this module accurately record data while accelerating over 100g's?

Question: Can you tell me the voltage output? I'm wondering if I could connect this directly to an IR Blaster. Thank you.
Answer: Spec sheet for the IC is here ( http://www.invensense.com/mems/gyro/documents/PS-MPU-6000A-00v3.4.pdf ), and it looks like this board has a linear regulator to let the 3.3V chip be supplied from 5V. So it looks like the outputs are at 3.3V. If that's the voltage of your IR blaster and the protocols are compatible, sure. If you're looking to use the 'Digital Motion Processor', you'll need to figure out how to program it -- I never took the time to.

Question: Should I get the 211z or the 211K? Any difference in the two?
Answer: While the box says it includes a 211K it will contain a 211z. I sent my original order back because it had a 211z and I wanted a 211k the second unit was the same I just kept it. The difference is the outputs the 211k has a coax output and the 211z has a HDMI output as far as I know nothing else is different. For use in an RV you have to check if you have coax (usually older) or hdmi (usually newer) input - some might have both. Nonetheless you can purchase an inexpensive adapter that goes from the RCA Jacks (on both) to coax. If you go directly to the TV via HDMI you will not have satellite at the bedroom tv. If this is not for RV use then 211z will hook directly to your flat screen TV and provide you a excellent picture.

Question: i want to know how much area is covered by single mic of this type. What is the radius of area which can be covered by single mic
Answer: I cannot give you a precise answer but I have information that might help. I have a 12'x24' conference room with a 4'x16' table in the middle of the room that seats 4 people on each side. I have a CM-1000USB microphone in the middle of the table and 2 CM-1000 microphones attached to it on each side (about 5' from center). In a recent meeting, with people in the room and people in several remote locations, the presenter walked around the room the whole time. Even though the presenter wasn't wearing a microphone, the 3 microphones on the table picked her up so well that people in the remote locations had no difficulty hearing the presenter. Note that our meeting software has an audio meter and I am able to adjust microphone volume in Windows, if needed. I rarely need to adjust microphone volume (unless there is somebody who is, truly, softspoken talking). Note, as well, that as with any omni-directional microphone, that all sounds within the range of the microphone are picked up. So, if someone at the table is speaking and someone else is drumming their fingers on the table, both are picked up by the microphone. There are situations where a uni-directional or bi-directional microphone might be more appropriate than an omni-directional microphone.

Question: Can this microphone be used with voice recognition software?
Answer: I doubt it would perform well. This is an omni-directional microphone. A directional mike would be better for voice recognition.

Question: Is there any benefit to getting the USB version over the 3.5mm aux version?
Answer: Yes and no. For one microphone attached to a standard Mac or PC, I suggest the USB model as it has has a built-in driver. If using something other than a standard Mac or PC, the 3.5mm Plug model might be a better choice as it would have no built-in driver. For two microphones attached to a standard Mac or PC, I suggest using one USB model and one 3.5mm Plug model plugged into one of the input jacks on the USB model (there are two inputs, the instructions indicate which input to use on the USB model). For multiple microphones attached to a standard Mac or PC, one USB model combined with one or more 3.5mm Plug models would be best. The USB model has both left and right inputs so that users can daisy-chain one or more 3.5mm Plug models into each input. If I had a 30-foot conference table, I could place the USB model in the middle of the table with two 3.5mm Plug models on one side and three 3.5mm Plug models on the other side for a total of 6 microphones on the table. I presently use a similar setup on a smaller table and get great audio unless somebody is drumming his fingers or tapping her pen on the table.

Question: Would this Sound Tech CM-1000 USB work well for voice control of a computer?
Answer: No, this an omni-directional microphone built to work in "sound all around" environments, such as conference rooms. For voice control, a directional (preferred) or bi-directional microphone (will work okay in many situations) would be much better because they focus on the voice and block background noise which, in turn, allows a computer to better understand the voice commands which results in increased accuracy.

Question: I broadcast whiteboard workshops via WebEx in a classroom what kind of pick up does this mic have? Will this support a large room like a classroom?
Answer: I have a 12'x24' conference room with a 4'x16' table in the middle of the room that seats 4 people on each side. I have a CM-1000USB microphone in the middle of the table and 2 CM-1000 microphones attached to it on each side (about 5' from center). In a recent meeting, with people in the room and people in several remote locations, the presenter wandered around the room constantly. Even though the presenter wasn't wearing a microphone, the 3 microphones on the table picked her up so well that people in the remote locations had no difficulty hearing the presenter. Note that our meeting software has an audio meter and I am able to adjust microphone volume in Windows, if needed. I rarely need to adjust microphone volume (unless there is somebody who is, truly, softspoken talking). Note, as well, that multiple CM-1000's can be daisy-chained into each of the 2 channels of a single CM-1000USB. I don't recall the recommended maximum number of CM-1000's per channel but I have heard of people using 3 or 4 in each channel without any issues. By the way, when daisy-chaining, it isn't necessary to have an equal number of CM-1000's in each channel. It is okay to have 1 in one channel and 2 in the other channel.

Question: Can you help me make it work for a Mac Mini? It doesn't work when plugged into the USB port.
Answer: The Sound Tech CM-1000USB is a standard USB microphone that can be plugged into a USB port on a PC or Mac (including the Mac Mini). If the mic doesn't, I would try another USB microphone. If another mic works, I would wonder if the CM-1000USB is defective. If another mic doesn't work, I would follow the steps in the articles below to debug. 1. http://www.ehow.com/how_5254822_use-mic-mac-mini.html 2. http://forums.appleinsider.com/t/61148/mac-mini-and-usb-microphone 3. http://forums.macrumors.com/showthread.php?t=1367478

Question: Is it just a matter of feeding this a step and direction, or does this need the A/B signals phased correctly for a stepper?
Answer: This does not handle steppers directly (step/dir) and you must apply the phase signals properly. There are lots of methods to do this but the easiest is with a microcontroller. Another example: http://www.theremin.us/Circuit_Library/bioplar_stepper_motor.htm

Question: Will i be able to use a 12v power supply with this? i'm confused on what "can board to take power +5v" means.
Answer: Yes. With a 12v supply, use the onboard voltage regulator to supply the onboard 5v. There will be either a switch or jumper to use the onboard regulator. Don't supply over 16v volts with the regulator activated, or it will fry. Gooogle "L298 Users guide"

Question: there are jumpers and a switch. anyone know how to add a resistor to set the current limit or what the jumpers are for ?
Answer: There are several flavors of this board out there so I may be incorrect. The switch simply gates the supply to and from the VCC regulator. The jumpers I believe go to the enable signals for each motor. As for the current limit, I believe you will have to limit the motor supply input current in some way. You can find the datasheet for the IC here: https://www.sparkfun.com/datasheets/Components/General/L298N.pdf

Question: i need 6 speakers, all will be outside. can two transmittars transmit to 6 speakers at the same time from the same source (a smsrtphone)
Answer: I am not sure. The source has to plug directly into the transmitter. The speakers are wireless and need power from an outlet (no batteries) as does the transmitter. But the source needs a 3.5 mm (headphone size) cable to connect to each transmitter. You could try a Y cable but the transmitters could interfere with each other, I haven't used 2 so I don't know if they would interfere. I have my transmitter plugged into a sonos connect so I can use the sonos system to have wireless music with my smart phone and have outdoor speakers because sonos doesn't make one for outdoors.

Question: Can I run speaker wires from my receiver into these or do I have to use an MP3 player?
Answer: You can't run speaker wires but it has a 3.5 mm input on the transmitter. It's the size you use for headphones. If your receiver has a headphone out jack you can plug that into transmitter and then wirelessly transmit sound to speakers. The transmitter has to be plugged into a power outlet as does each speaker.

Question: Do they need to be plugged in to AC or are they battery operated also?

Question: can i use version fios
Answer: Yes it's almost like it was made for Verizon Fios. You need one Ethernet/Coax adapter; 2 RG6 cables and a 2.5ghz bi-directional splitter. Don't use the coax out on the Ethernet/Coax adapter or you will lose On Demand and Guide. Split coax from wall and run to the adapter and STB. Follow this guide http://www.dslreports.com/faq/15984

Question: All the splitters in my house are 1GHZ, including a Coax AMP. Would I need to switch all the splitters out in order to get this device to work?
Answer: You need 2 GHz splitters and no amps in the signal path between the MoCA boxes. Splitters not in the path don't matter. If the cable runs to each MoCA box are on separate amp outputs, then combine the runs on outputs of a splitter fed by a single amp output.

Question: Wireless router is in a different room, ps4 has a weak signal. Can i use this for coax in, and then coax out to TV, as well as ethernet to ps4?
Answer: i had issues with both the ethernet and coax speed when i used this to split both. i would recommend using a coax splitter to have the TV signal NOT run though this adapter. then, assuming that your coax network is part of your router's LAN, use this to convert coax to ethernet for the PS4. assuming that you have FIOS, refer to this for networking info: http://www.dslreports.com/faq/verizonfios/3.0_Networking

Question: Can I split the signal going out of the adapter and into a gigabit ethernet switch?
Answer: If you mean can you send the ethernet/network output into a switch - yes, definitely, I do this at home for a home office. The other output (the built-in split) is the cable and you'd send that to a TV or set top box, etc - that's not network, but RF.

Question: Does this work with AT&T U-verse? If so, will one of these MoCA devices allow me to split the coax going into the DVR and provide ethernet to the TV?
Answer: Yes, it should work just fine. You will run one cable off the coax splitter into the DVR and the other into the Actiontec. And you will have your Ethernet for the TV, providing that your U-verse router is MoCA enabled. The splitter I have been using is the RCA DH24SPF Two Way 3 Ghz Bi-Directional Splitter.

Question: I have internet from Centurylink from my HOA and cable from Comcast. do I need this adapter for a Tivo Roamio plus or the basic Roamio?
Answer: you don't actually need it for your cablework with either Roamio. I strongly suggrst that you call Tiiiivo and ma ke sure the Roamio works with your cable system and then talk to them about using the actiontec MOCA. some cable and satellite systems wont work with Roamio.

Question: Warrantee
Answer: Yes.

Question: Can I use the Actiontec to connect my antenna cable output to my wireless router so I can stream to a TV with Roku in another room?
Answer: No. The reason is that the ActionTec is designed to handle mix of ActionTec router sending out information over Ethernet connected to one ActionTec unit in this listing over coax cable instead of cat 5 or 6 network cable. But using the same coax cable for the TV antenna signals plus Ethernet does not mix. Yes you can solve that with more special devices, but in this case you are better off running a separate antenna cable, as that is the less expensive solution.

Question: where is microphone
Answer: If you use a magnifying lens, you can see a small thin horizontal slot in the front of the unit just below the two small push buttons. The slot is centered on the spot where the two push buttons meet, and a fraction of an inch (about 1 mm) just below them. That is the microphone input area, and the microphone itself is just behind the slot inside the camera unit. The camera itself has a view hole whose diameter is the same as the microphone slot height (i.e. a pinhole) that is horizontally in-line with the microphone slot, and about half way toward the LED indicator. Both are itty bitty devices, but they have worked well for me, and the small size prevents most dust and dirt buildup. It's pretty much the same technology as used on smart phones, but the camera is much lower resolution due to the real-time transmission constraints of a video call so it doesn't have or need a lens.

Question: Does this come with the power cord that connects to a USB port? It's not shown in the pictures. Also, is eSATA supposed to be faster than USB 2 or 3
Answer: The product description lists a power cord is included. It is more important that this comes with a mini CD with the correct drivers. I have purchased three of these pci-express cards with USB 3.0 and with and without eSATA. The USB3.0 and eSATA ports I/O speed is limited by the pcie bus. USB3.0 should be faster than the pcie bus but you must remember that there are several controller and bridge chips between the storage device and the computer. The all can add overhead and bottle necks. In my testing I have found the max Read/Write speeds to be 70-120MBps for USB3.0 and eSATA. The eSATA is temperamental and I only use for backup. The max Read/Write speeds I get for USB2.0 are 30-40MBps. So this card is useful to use an open pci-express slot to add USB3.0/eSATA ports that are 2X-3X faster than your USB2.0. As far as power, I have not had to use the external power for accessing USB3.0 HDDs or SSDs. I have found huge variations in I/O speeds between different external enclosures with the same drives installed. I say go for it if you have an empty slot and only USB2.0 and also consider a dual USB3.0 unless you require eSATA. One answer referred to unstable behavior on a laptop. That is caused by the driver. The USB/eSATA card uses a different driver than the dual USB card. The included driver may not be the best for your PC, but there is probably a better driver somewhere..

Question: can this jib exceed 12'' in length?
Answer: Do not attempt to extend the length of this jib. The legs on the stand are not wide enough to support the added mass without the jib toppling, and adding sandbags to the stand will run the risk of damaging the legs. For anything longer, you may want to consider a Kessler Crane jib, or one of the other higher priced jibs designed for such work. Keep in mind, there's also the weight of the camera which gets magnified many times, the longer the jib boom is, and that means more weight on the counter balance end. ProAm will not honor warranties under situations like this.

Question: I see people talking about a tilt tool, and a base within the questions. Can i get some direct links of what is recommended to purchase with the crane

Question: concerning the 12v + / - where is the best place to locate the negative wire on the 12v side?
Answer: The voltage reducer if it is the 48 V to 12V one is designed to go across all batteries. Therefore you connect the positive side to the positive terminal on one end of the battery system and the negative on the negative terminal at the other end of the battery series. If you have 8V batteries there should be 6 batteries hooked up in series between the negative and positive connections.

Question: Does it work for an 2008 Club Car precedent?
Answer: There are 2 different voltage reducers available, one for a 48 volt cart and the other for a 36 volt cart. You need the one that matches the voltage of your cart. If you are unsure what the voltage of your cart is, measure the voltage of one of the batteries and multiply by the number of batteries. The total voltage may be a volt or two above the 36 or 48 volt level. For instance, a good set of 8 volt batteries that are fully charged will measure around 50 volts. You want the voltage reducer closest to the total. I hope that this helps!!!

Question: I would like to see a wiring diagram, can anyone help?
Answer: There really isn't a wiring diagram. There are 4 wires, each clearly marked. The four wires are +48 VDC In (+ side of battery array), Ground in (- side of battery array), +12 VDC Out and GND (-) Out. Connect the input side to your battery array and the output side to whatever 12 volt device you need to power. Keep in mind that there is a 10 Amp limit, which should be plenty for most applications, but something to be aware of.

Question: Can this be used to charge a 12v battery?
Answer: No, this is not a charger, it reduces the voltage from a 48 volt battery pack to 12 volts so that 12 volt accessories use all the batteries equally.

Question: Can I connect this unit to a 48VDC battery set and reduce and achieve 12VDC to power a car radio system?

Question: What else will i need to go with this system? i see people mentioning recievers.
Answer: Firstly, these are great speakers for an average size room. I have them installed in my family room and they are terrific. Many people hook them up to a "receiver" (which can do a number of things). Mine is a Onkyo through which everything is "processed." The Onkyo has inputs/outputs for my (old tech) VCR, my DVD, my Netflix input and my DirectTV cable box. It also has an AM/FM receiver built in and is remotely controlled. Switching from mode to another is simple and painless. The output from the Onkyo goes directly to my LCD TV, my speakers and back to the VCR (yes I still have one) for recording. So, in sum, if you buy a TV, the speakers and a receiver/amp you're in business. A Sony BluRay (with built-in Netflix, Hulu, etc.) is really inexpensive and also a necessary as far as I am concerned. Hope this helps.

Question: Are the speakers 4, 6 or 8 ohm?

The recommended compatible part number is KTL-TP3CL/4G, found here: http://www.amazon.com/Kingston-Technology-PC3-12800-KTL-TP3CL-4G/dp/B00D74FQP0/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1432661623&sr=1-1&keywords=KTL-TP3CL%2F4G Thank you for choosing Kingston as your upgrade partner! -Jewel, Kingston US Technical Support

Question: Will this work in my HP2000z laptop?
Answer: Hi Brian, There appear to be a few diferent HP Pavilion 2000z series notebook models, the dv2000z, tx2000z, and ze2000z. All these systems are not compatible with DDR3 memory. The first two use DDR2 memory and the third uses DDR memory. Part number KVR16S11S8/4 is DDR3 and would not be compatible with those systems. There is also the HP 2000z-2a00 CTO which is a newer system and should work with this 4GB module. Be sure to verify the exact model of your system and check it's service manual for memory compatibility specifications. Thank you for your interest in Kingston ValueRAM, -Jewel, Kingston US Technical Support

Question: will it fit alienware alpha?
Answer: Hi Bijan, The Alienware Alpha uses DDR3L-1600 memory modules. Part number KVR16S11S8/4 is DDR3-1600. The difference is that the DDR3L is low voltage (1.35V) and DDR3 is standard voltage (1.5V). The low voltage version is KVR16LS11/4, found here: http://www.amazon.com/Kingston-Technology-1600MHz-PC3-12800-KVR16LS11/dp/B00CQ35GYE/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1428945137&sr=1-1&keywords=KVR16LS11%2F4 Thank you for choosing Kingston as your upgrade partner! -Jewel, Kingston US Technical Support

Question: will this work for lenovo flex 2
Answer: Hi Eli, The Lenovo Flex 2 requires low voltage (1.35V) memory and part number KVR16S11S8/4 is standard voltage (1.5V). The low voltage version of this part that will work, can be found here: http://www.amazon.com/Kingston-Technology-1600MHz-PC3-12800-KVR16LS11/dp/B00CQ35GYE/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1426174600&sr=1-1&keywords=kvr16ls11+4 Thank you for choosing Kingston as your upgrade partner! -Jewel, Kingston US Technical Support

Question: will this work with hp s5 1204 64 bit
Answer: Hi Kathy, This memory is not compatible with the HP Pavilion Slimline s5-1204 desktop. That system requires dual rank 4GB DDR3-1333 memory modules and this memory is a single rank 4GB DDR3-1600 memory module. We no longer manufacture memory that is compatible with that system. You might be able to find the discontinued compatible part number KTH9600B/4G from some online resellers. Thank you for considering Kingston ValueRAM, -Jewel, Kingston US Technical Support

Question: Does this actually work on a full-frame body as the description mentions? I have a similar-looking one that works on my 50D but not my 5D Mark III
Answer: A full manual k mount lens has no machanical protrusions to adjust your aperture. These I feel are the safe ones the adapter is made for. I would look at the back of an EF mount lens and measure from the camera mirror when off you should be able to lift to a position that is far out as it will go. If you like it, go for it. I have a ID MK4 and will only use EF mounts even with the 1.3 sensor. Just looking at the lenses that are full manual film lenses, they look like they will work. Any other i won't comment anymore for, to many protrusions sticking to the mirror box. My manual lenses all work great with the adapter.

Question: What is the difference between these and the Monster Powerbeats by Dr. Dre that are going for $62.95?
Answer: Here's what I understand. Monster Power beats are not what are pictured here. What the image shows are Powerbeats by Dre, the athletic in-ear headphones. Monster Power beats are the over the ear headphones. They are actually much more expensive (close to double the price.) The listing for $62.50 looks like it's from a discount business, so I would be careful. It might be fine, but you might be getting a refurbished set of earphones. Then again, because of the difference between the models, I would make sure you know which one you're getting. Over the ear, or in-ear. Here is a link to the official site so you can compare MSRPs and models. http://www.beatsbydre.com/collection/?cid=PS_google_beats%20by%20dre_Evergreen_Core+Terms_us_na&mkwid=sp6qTczgI|dc_pcrid_46072598937_pkw_beats%20by%20dre_pmt_e&migMedium=paid-search&migSource=google&migContent=s&migCampaign=Brand+Beats+Electronics+-+Exact&migTerm=beats%20by%20dre&matchtype=e
